Story: 8/10
The story has a nice, organized, strong structure which allows a good foothold for a nice story to develop off of it. The concept itself is very fascinating, and I think the author did a fantastic job at executing it with a tale like this. It was clear that a lot of research had been made to make sure that information was accurate (i.e. the demons and the Vatican). While the pacing occasionally felt a bit slow, the show was still capable of picking it up with more serious segments. 
Art: 7/10 
I was pretty impressed with how the art and animation went downfor this show. While I'm not a HUGE fan of certain character designs, the speed and intensity of the animation was enough for me to leave that bit a little off the hook. What I admire most is that it never felt like A1 Pictures was trying to save money on certain episodes by limiting movement or anything like that: every episode was perfect and spot-on. 


Sound: 9/10 

I immensely enjoyed the soundtrack of this show: something which I don't say very often, considering that sound in an anime doesn't always catch my attention easily. The soundtrack, put together by Hiroyuki Sawano (who has also done shows like Kill la Kill, Attack on Titan, and Owari no Seraph), is fun, upbeat, and beautifully composed: not only does it nicely compliment the setting, but it's also great to listen to separately. The soundtrack also feels very diverse, going from funky modern beats to melodic orchestral pieces: there should be a track in it that everyone enjoys. 


Characters: 6/10 

One of my main problems with the show was its supporting characters, and it's not because they weren't creative or didn't have much depth, but because they just weren't very interesting. With a few exceptions, a lot of them felt very bland and stereotypical, and their personalities weren't enough to make me want to latch onto them emotionally. I think it's most likely because their struggles and back stories hardly compare to the struggles of the main characters, so the viewer tends to feel like they have less of a drive to them. And we hardly get to see in detail what those struggles and back stories look like. Meanwhile, Rin and Yukio have a very tragic story, which drowns out the history of the other supporting characters so the viewer focuses more on them. 


However, my rating for character is generous, because even if they weren't very intriguing, I still found them enjoyable to watch. 


Enjoyment: 7/10 

I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy this show. The funny and tricky situations, along with the colorful cast of characters, gave some good humor to the show. There are good moments to it, especially good heartwarming ones, bits that I won't forget. My attachment to the main characters was what got me through it, and it's definitely worth watching for that reason. My only problem is that the show's certain shtick can get a little old, but overall, it was amusing to watch. 


Overall: 8/10 

I'd say that to anyone who's interested in action-comedy anime, this show is worth your while! The show has a nice story, with cool animation and a great soundtrack. While the supporting characters could use a bit of an upgrade, they are still fun to watch with the well-written main characters. And as for anyone in which action or comedy isn't exactly their cup of tea, I still recommend that you at least give the 1st episode a watch.

Imagine you’ve lived the last 15 years of your life with your priest foster father at a monastery along with your twin brother. You’ve gone to school, maybe gotten into a few fights, but as far as the world at large is concerned you’re normal. Now imagine that, on what may as well be any other day, you are attacked by a demon, saved by your foster father who turns out to be an Exorcist, and told that you’re the son of satan. And then your foster dad is killed by your real dad. Sweet. For Rin Okumura, all that is an unfortunate reality.
Before hecan stop to really take stock of what has happened Rin is thrust into a world where demons are a part of everyday life and one of the country’s most prestigious high schools is actually the True Cross Academy for training Exorcists. Oh, and his brother has been going there for years without him knowing. And he’s now Rin’s teacher. Double sweet. Rin vows to grow stronger to take revenge on satan for what he has done, but before he can do anything he needs to learn to get on with his classmates and, y’know, study.


Ao no Exorcist starts off very strong, throwing both you and Rin into unfamiliar territory before you can stop to ask any questions. Learning about Rin’s heritage, the actual state of the world and the ways of True Cross Academy will very quickly grip you and get you interested in both the characters and plot itself. While the middle of the series is still very entertaining, it sags a little as the writers can’t seem to decide whether they want to advance the plot, develop characters or just randomly muck around. Don’t get me wrong though, every episode is just as good as the last on its own, it’s just that the way they come together to tell the overall story isn’t as well done as it could have been. The ending, while still on par with the rest of the series quality-wise, felt very premature, with little indication that the conclusion of the story was coming up before the last few episodes.


I probably say this too much, but Ao no Exorcist could very easily have been a longer series. As it was, it felt like the writers were rushed into the final arc before they had laid down the groundwork for it (and the manga is still continuing, so there you go). Side characters that were really quite well done weren’t given the attention they deserved, being presented as important but remaining relatively insignificant to the main plot. The variety of abilities they possessed had a lot of potential that was never realized, and their role within True Cross Academy and the True Cross Order of Exorcists could also have been developed further. There’s also a slight problem with consistency in power levels, with Rin simply powering up DBZ-style to tackle any obstacle that comes his way. I was left waiting for a training sequence that never came (well, it was mentioned, but never really explored).


It may sound like there’s a huge amount the series fails to get right, but the only reason I’ve identified so many faults is because of how much I enjoyed watching the series in the first place. These aren’t problems that need to be fixed, just areas that could have been improved to make the experience even better than it already was. It should say something about the concept itself that it can have so many gaps while still supporting such an engaging tale.


The animation was also of a very high quality; from facial expressions to background scenery, everything is pleasing to look at and the character designs themselves are also excellent. The animation studio can be very proud of their work here.

Ao no Exorcist, a shounen which has become immensely popular in both anime and manga, loved by many but also disliked/hated by others. A show which started well enough, but soon went downhill quickly due to many plot holes and filler crap.
I'm just going to put this out here right now: the anime version of Ao no Exorcist has filler 2nd half and ending. Yes, the 2nd half is mostly a filler. It does not stick with the manga for the most parts and is therefore punished by it. For those who are looking to watch Ao no Exorcist, I suggest you to watch thefirst half of the show, (about until 16-17 episodes or so) then go read the manga for the rest, especially if you don't want to be disappointed by the filler half. 


Story- 6/10

The premise of the show is interesting enough. Satan, demons, exorcists, and the two separated worlds of Gehenna and Assiah, the concept of this show seems pretty good at first, however, it turns out to be yet another typical shounen, set mostly in a school setting with some flat romance. 

The first half is good enough, mostly keeping with the manga. The first couple of episodes are probably the best episodes of the series, showing the main characters, bits of our main antagonist, and introductions of the True Cross Academy, and both Gehenna and Assiah. It's decent enough, and I was actually enjoying it up to this point (like up to episode 8 or so) However the episodes that follow don't do the same. The 2nd half which I have said before, is mostly a filler arc, which doesn't stay true to the manga, and just makes their own story up which turned out to be, well, horrible. There are just so many plot holes in the anime as a whole, and a rushed ending makes the quick downfall of the show. 


Art- 8/10

One of the best parts of the series comes from the Art/Animation. Although some character designs were lacking in parts, it is still very acceptable. The art is mostly comprised of bright colors, but also feature some darker aspects depending on the scene. I have to say that it complemented the scenes well. The animation is smooth and the characters move well. Overall it is very good.


Sound- 7/10

The composer of the show's soundtrack is Hiroyuki Sawano, who has also composed other stand-out soundtracks for many popular anime like Attack on Titan, Guilty Crown, and Kill la Kill. The battle osts are pretty epic, and it fit the scenes well, however, outside of those osts, nothing else stood out. The OP/ED were catchy enough, I personally didn't like it, but maybe you could find them likable. 


Character- 6/10

The characters were good, but didn't have much depth into them. Rin was by far the best character of the series, with bits of calm and cool personality showing through as the show went on. Yukio, although he is the younger brother, he still acts like the older one and is much more mature in situations than the rest of the gang. Finally, Shiemi is a love interest for Rin,   and is one of the few characters who actually show character development in the series. The rest of the characters were too shallow and lacked depth overall.


Enjoyment- 6/10

I enjoyed the show for some parts. Like I have said already, the first couple of episodes were good and enjoyable. The rest of the episodes suffered from too many plot holes and filler. The actions were decent enough, but ultimately led to nothing in the end. 


Overall- 5/10

I was let down by the anime. I love the manga series, and when I heard that Ao no Exorcist was going to get a anime, I was very excited. However, it lacked direction, and couldn't stay true to the manga for the most parts. Ao no Exorcist is interesting enough at the first glance, good and enjoyable first couple of episodes, but the rest that followed were a mess. I enjoyed parts of it to be fair, but still disliked the series as a whole. I wouldn't exactly recommend this, but who knows, others could find it enjoyable.

Well, I don't know that there's a lot to be said about this anime, considering its age and that it's already pretty widely viewed.

Uuh, with characters, honestly, I would have liked to see more development and focus among the side characters. The only one who really go through any kind of dynamic change is  Shiemi, of all characters. Everyone else pretty much stays the same, and the anime never really goes into anyone's backstory, which is also annoying. The one saving grace is that many of the characters are very charismatic. That being said, I rate this a 7. Definitely worth the watch, but I don't think I'll be watching this anime again.

If a person out of the "blue", no pun intended had asked me which was the better one of two series that revolved around exorcism, would it be Blue Exorcist? or D.Gray-Man? in all honesty, i have to go with the former, as it has a more realistic portrayal towards the side of exorcism itself.
Blue Exorcist is the story of two young men, twin brothers, the older but dumber Rin Okumura and the younger but smarter Yukio Okumura, as they alongside family, friends and allies battle the forces of Satan himself, determined to take over not only Hell but also Earth, as well.
The series focuseson the relationship between these two brothers who are, as different, as both day and night whilst learning to become exorcists, the primary defense force for Humans against Satan who use religious aspects of all different religions known to the world to help them in their war against the ever invading forces of Hell.


The major theme of Blue Exorcist itself is about family, of how strong bonds exist between family members, be they blood related or not, such is the case for the Okumura brothers, having been raised by the church all their lives without knowing the true identities of their parents and instead were primarily raised by their foster father, the priest of the church named Shiro Fujimoto.


Due to certain circumstances, Rin, the primary protagonist of the story discovers from Shiro that both he and Yukio are actually the sons of Satan and that Satan needs at least one of them in order to open the gates of Hell to the Human world for Satan himself cannot, being trapped on the other side.


Rin unlike Yukio upon reaching maturity had already awakened without him knowing Satan's blood within him, giving Rin the ability to see things that normal Humans cannot and even more so especially, the ability to produce blue colored flames, the signature of Satan.


Because of this, Rin is targeted by Satan to be used, as the means of freeing himself from Hell, however, in a desperate attempt to save his son from Satan's evil machinations, Shiro gladly gives up his life to allow Rin to continue living a life of his choosing and not of others.


Upon Shiro's death, the order of exorcists that he belonged to, the True Cross Order find Rin and give him the option of a peaceful death at their hands, for now that Shiro is dead and he was the only one capable of protecting both Rin and Yukio from the order in secret all their lives, now that Rin has awakened to the devil's blood within him, the exorcists have been given strict orders to eliminate him before he becomes a potential threat to the safety of all Humanity...


However, Rin shocks them, as he remembers that Shiro gave up his life for Rin, wanting to honor the legacy of his father, Rin decides for himself that instead of dying he will instead learn to become a exorcist himself by using the demonic power born within him to destroy Satan, he will learn to become an exorcist one way or another and will take on any that gets in his way, be they demons or exorcists alike...


Mephisto Pheles, a close friend of Shiro's and the one in charge of Rin's execution finds the idea of "a demon killing Satan" to be amusing, simply just because of this, Mephisto being the only one who knows about Rin from within the order decides to hold off his execution and allow Rin to be inducted into the order, as an exorcist in training, wanting to see how far he will go to prove his determination of vengeance, will he die along the path or will he actually be able to kill Satan? either way, its sure to be amusing...


Thus Rin's career and adventure into being an exorcist begins, what will await him remains unknown but either way, he intends to cut through fate itself and  prove his Humanity, by using but denying his demon heritage, Rin intends to avenge Shiro and live up to his legacy, to honor the man that gave Rin what was ultimately needed for him: a choice and a chance to live life on his own terms.


Blue Exorcist is a great series to get into, it may not feature a whole lot of fight sequences but i think just the personalities of the characters alone makes the series enduring, it can be slow paced in some certain areas but it gradually builds up over time, the character of Rin Okumura is especially amusing, as he has a few things notable about him that are different to standard Shonen genre based series protagonists, the character Mephisto Pheles can easily be declared the series' breakout character due to his personality and charm, especially given his particular to blur on whose side he's truly on, an adding point to the success of Mephisto's character goes to his Japanese Seiyu voice actor Hiroshi Kamiya who gives the character a form of swag that makes him all the more likable.


Story, Art, Sound, Character, Enjoyment and Overall deserve high points each, Blue Exorcist is a more or less relatively new series but it certainly does have the potential to grow into something bigger then it already is, not much to say besides that other then to definitely give the series a bash, it might end up, as a fan favorite on your list of Manga/Anime series.

Ao No Exorcist is a very average anime in my eyes, and one that I think most casuals or newcomers to anime will thoroughly enjoy but when I am afraid that when it comes to people who have already seen a decent amount of anime it will fall into mediocrity and soon be forgotten. 
The characters are rather bland and have very clear-cut personalities, with the main character Rin Okumura being an average teenage guy who tries his best to be a good guy but is lazy and shirks his responsibilities. Rin is one of the most generic looking anime characters that I have everseen, he truly is just a normal black-haired teen who wears normal clothes. His only defining traits appearance-wise are his horns and tail that protrude when he becomes angry. He is also hot-headed and quick to act without thinking. Of course his younger brother Yukio is the responsible type and often does his best to keep Rin's priorities straight. These two personalities clash and provide a decent amount of humour in the show but the roles themself are certainly nothing ground breaking. Rin is also a character whom I feel is meant to be an avatar that the viewer can live out their fantasy through, similar to Kirito from Sword Art Online. Ironically, Rin and Kirito also have the same english VA which may have influenced me thinking of him like that. \n
Speaking of voices, the overall english dub is well put together and features veterans of the field such as Johnny Yong Bosch and Kyle Hebert, and since the cast is experienced it makes for an excellent dub. As for the rest of the sound aspects, the music is not very engaging and does not hype up action scenes much or impact serious scenes as much I would like. Additionally the OP/ED's are average but easy to forget. \n
Action in Ao No Exorcist is few and far between and normally not very entertaining. You will either be watching characters shooting at generic demons, reading bible verses, or ending battles with a single swipe of a sword. This is when battles are shown, as the series frustratingly has action taking place out-of-frame frequently during big moments and instead decides to focus on the spectators' reactions to the fight rather than showing the battle itself. There are many times where it seems like two characters are about to seriously duke it out 1v1, but Ao No Exorcist never successfully capitalises on these fight opportunities. Fight scenes are very short and the animation behind them is far from spectacular.\n
Where the series really shines is in it's comedy and slice of life elements, but as funny as the comedic bits are they don't come up quite enough to keep the viewer as engaged as they should be. Almost every episode has a hysterical laugh-out-loud moment, but episodes should have MORE than one moment like that. The series also abandons comedy altogether for some episodes and especially near the end of the series. It almost feels as if this show was supposed to be a long-running shonen because the main character only finds out he has powers right in the beginning of the anime and then must work to properly learn to harness them as the series progresses. But the thing is, hardly any progress seems to be made in this area yet Rin still seems to win most battles with ease.\n
If you are looking for an average show to kill some time, Ao No Exorcist is a good choice and it should keep you entertained for most of the runtime, but don't expect any lasting impact. There are far better shows with better plot, characters, fight scenes, and takeaways, but Ao No Exorcist is a wonderful show to turn your brain off and enjoy!

Right, Blue Exorcist. A world in which there are cute demon boys, where exorcists fight with weapons rather than just recite Bible verses, and telling the story of two brothers with a rift between them.
Story: 7/10
Surprisingly enough for a shounen series, Blue Exorcist is actually pretty heavily character-driven, so going into too much detail on the story would lead into a character discussion.
Right from the start, the story is pretty trope-y, and it progresses in what you'd call the most logical manner. Twin brothers, sons of Satan, one of whom has demonic powers and the other one who is an exorcist fighting them. Rin, ourmain character who has Satan's powers, decides that he'll become an exorcist to, in his words, "beat the shit out of Satan."

Honestly, if you just watch the first episode and drop the show, you'll probably think that this is super cliched of a premise and not very interesting. However, if you continue, you'll see how the characters are written, and that is where the show truly shines.

Despite A-1 Pictures usually being pretty faithful to the source material, with Blue Exorcist they decided to go off-script and do an anime-original ending. The show basically crashes and burns when that happens, and it's painfully obvious when the show does move into anime-original. It develops plot up the ass, it gets super forced and over the top, and it's impossible to take seriously. Not to mention the characters are out of character and basically destroy the premise of the show. We get to see history on Rin and his brother Yukio's mother, but it's written really ridiculously and is basically a lot of "Awwww Satan, you're not evil, just lonely" and "I LOVE YOU SATAN, AND ALL THE EXORCISTS IN THE WORLD COULDN'T STOP OUR LOVE" and is just so bad you can't help but laugh. I didn't feel any sort of emotional attachment to these last few episodes, but kept watching in the hopes that it'd redeem itself (it didn't).

It's such a shame that they did go anime-original, because the plot was doing so well up until that point. So why did they? One of my friends said it was because the arc the manga was on wouldn't have made a very good ending, but honestly, anything would have been a better ending than what they gave us. If they couldn't possibly have avoided anime-original, they should've hired better writers that didn't make cringe-worthy material.

The story still gets 7/10 though, just because it was doing so well up until the end.


An interesting choice of narrative was having this be focused on Christianity (though the religion itself isn't used much; it's mostly as support for the exorcist scenario), which isn't a common religion in Japan. I think this might be an alternate universe where Christianity is the leading religion in Japan, since all the relevant characters are Christian and the school Rin goes to is basically its own town, and I doubt there's many Christian schools like that in Japan.


Blue Exorcist also has a lot of comedic relief to lighten the mood. Normally in other shows it's ineptly done and can ruin the scene, but I actually found the comedy to be quite funny and not disruptive like I was expecting. It definitely made me laugh out loud a lot, and I think that says something as compared to most other shows.


Art: 8/10

Not much to say here. It was good, as expected of A-1. I didn't really notice any problems, but there weren't really any moments that were amazingly impressive. The character animation and the opening and ending sequences were fine, though I have some issues with the second ED sequence since it's mostly stills and textures and the animation is done around the stills as a transitional effect like a PowerPoint.


Sound: 9/10

The openings and endings of this show are really good. The first OP took a little getting used to, but it grew on me. They're overall really catchy songs and fit well with the show.

The OST of this show is really good as well. It's done by Hiroyuki Sawano, and while I can't say I'm as fond of this soundtrack as I am of Attack on Titan's and Kill la Kill's, it was pretty good still. The soundtrack was ambient noise a lot of the times, with good stuff happening during the battles. There was a large variety in sound too, and I don't really recall hearing the same tracks over and over again, which is always refreshing.


The dub of this show is really good as well. Bryce Papenbrook is perfect as Rin, and the other actors were all doing great work. I haven't seen the Japanese version (except for the first episode a while back), but I'm sure that's really good too.


Characters: 8/10

This was easily the strongest point of the show until it all went downhill, but I'll get to that later.

As previously mentioned, Blue Exorcist is pretty character-driven for a shounen series, and the characters are really strong. We see a lot of focus on their backstories and motivations, and time is even set aside for the minor characters developing on their own, not necessarily because of Rin or to establish relationships with him.


Rin himself is a pretty generic but relatable shounen lead. He's angry a good portion of the time, wants to fight everyone, and has something to prove. He also is a strong believer in doing what's right, and at this point you're probably groaning over how cliched he is. Yet despite his temper, Rin is shown to be surprisingly sensitive and sympathetic to other characters, and is actually just a big softie. Plus, he's a really good cook, and uses his skills to make others feel happy. That's not really a trait you see in many other shounen protagonists. Even as a child, before he knew he was Satan's son, he was shunned by parents and their kids, and called a "demon child." This has a big role in leading to him being compassionate as a teenager. Rin's aggressive toward those that show him animosity, but around his friends, he tries as hard as he can to be kind.

Since he has Satan's powers, he's the embodiment of the creatures exorcists are supposed to fight, and often has trouble keeping his powers under control around his fellow exorcists-in-training. This can lead to some humorous moments with the whole "I can't let them find out about me" thing.

Rin also has a complicated relationship with his twin brother Yukio. This was another really good choice of character, since siblings in anime are usually either really close or want to kill each other. Yukio finds Rin to blame for some of the stuff that's happened to them, and Rin often loses his temper around Yukio, but the next minute they're laughing and joking together. It's a pretty accurate depiction of real sibling relationships, actually.


As for Yukio, as much as I tried to dislike him for his initial harsh treatment of Rin, I ended up liking him just as much. You can't really blame him for the way he acts sometimes, and he's shown to attempt understanding toward Rin. Like I said, they also display moments of their former closeness on occasion, so it's not all hate.

Yukio's also interesting because he too is the son of Satan, but since he was in too poor of health as a baby to handle Satan's powers, he is basically a normal human being. He doesn't face the same discrimination as Rin, which goes to show how much some blue flames and a tail can affect a person's perception.


There's a lot of interesting characters in this show, so I won't spent time detailing them all, but they are shown to be realistic characters with their own motivations and agendas, and we get backstory on most of them. The surprising depth to these characters really makes you care about them, and it's always exciting to see where they'll go next.

The other characters include Shiemi, the shy and clumsy girl who despite her timid nature has a strong willpower (though I have issues with the implied love triangle between her and the twins); Ryuuji, who's the tryhard classmate with a bone to pick against Rin; Izumo, the bitchy girl that takes advantage of Shiemi's kindness; Shura, who is basically a copycat of Yoko from Gurren Lagann but who is interesting nonetheless; and many others.


However, all of that changes once the show decides to deviate from the manga. The characters are reduced to their basic tropes and a lot of the depth is lost, and combined with the ludicrous narrative, it does not make for a good recipe. The characters were doing so well before then though.


Enjoyment: 8/10

I had a hell of a fun time with the show up until it became, very noticeably, anime-original. It was funny, action-packed, had well-written characters, and there was a lot of depth. As soon as it did deviate from the source material, I didn't enjoy it at all, unless you count that it was laughably bad. Which is why I need to read the manga.

Even despite the cringe-worthy last ten episodes or so, I still powered through the show in four days just because it was initially so addicting.


Overall: 8/10

So, should you watch Blue Exorcist? I say yes, at least until the anime-original story.

It's a strong shounen story that's pretty character-driven, and overcomes the flaws of its genre, only to later fall into the trap of "creative liberties."

Anyway, I feel like I haven't stated this enough: Blue Exorcist was really good until that point. I would have given it a 9 or something if it had kept up. Honestly, the only reason it's still as high as an 8 is BECAUSE it was so good until then, and it's a real shame that it had to change.

Shiemi was the love interest of Rin and only one among the others ones except Rin and Yukio that got any kind of character development. Most of the other ones were kind shallow. Ryuji was interesting with his backstory but then it was not that kind of interesting anymore.

At the very beginning of the series, I fell in love with it. The art style, the opening scene and music, all of it worked for me. However, the series seemed to end a bit too... prematurely for my taste.
Ao no Exorcist has some good fights and a typical knuckle headed hero (my favorite kind) and the supporting cast isn't that bad either. The whole twins concept was an interesting story element throughout the series, and the fact that the "younger" brother had the leash on his older brother was pretty hysterical. Even though Rin was a trouble maker who seemed to do nothing right,I found his redeeming quality of culinary arts very different compared to his exterior attitude.


The story of a half demon fighting yokai with a giant swords (stop me if that sounds familiar) has been given a bit of a fresh twist on it.The motivation of the main character to do so was something I had yet to see done in any series I've seen (admittedly not many overall) and it's definitely not comparable to Inuyasha; the fanservice is directed way more toward the male audience as a true shounen series. And what fanservice there is really isn't over the top.


Overall, as I stated earlier, the reason I harbor any bad feelings toward Ao no Exorcist was how it ended after setting up a perfect introduction to a second season. I know that some anime are just to promote interest in the original manga, but the ending just made my jaw drop and say "...AND?!?" It ended on a bright note which works for me- if the story feels resolved and not just yanked away from you to put your imagination to work. No one had come close to reaching their main goals, and the series just felt like a big tease to encourage reading the manga.

The first thing that I would say on Ao no Exorcist is that the Soundtrack Music is A-list Hollywood quality.  I fell in love with the soundtrack around episode 4, and since then, the music has never ceased to amaze me.  The composer and arranger, Hiroyuki Sawano, has managed to make a soundtrack that varies from tear-jerkingly beautiful to Hans Zimmer-quality Epic.  But, before I bore us all making love with a picture of Mr. Sawano, onto the rest of the story.  
If only the rest of Ao no Exorcist was as amazing as the music.  The premise is quiteShounen - You`ve got the son of Satan and a talented Twin - the typical rash sibling / calm sibling duo seen in everything from Fullmetal Alchemist to Clannad.  That said, the first few episodes stayed true to the manga, and seemed to be departing from its notably shounen premise.  That said, Ao no Exorcist`s plot, for the majority of the season, seemed quite reasonable, with a good pacing that seemed to suggest an ending similar to the manga and perhaps a sequel.  Yet, after around the 17th episode, things get weird.  Odd characters appear out of nowhere, and seemingly mundane characters return for odd cameos.  By no means is the plot bad - but it has long since lost the coherence of the first 10 episodes.  Instead, the plot has become something of a train wreck - still enjoyable by all means, but rushed and confusing.  The show is nearing its end now, with 22 out of 25 episodes under the belt--and though I look forwards to the ending, I am afraid it will be something that is so clearly cobbled together (As this last arc seems to be) that it will disappoint me.  


The art is nothing special - it is perfectly competent, and overall, the quality is never bad, but it brings little new to the table.  The characters as well are not deficient in any way, but they are nothing really revolutionary--as in most shounen anime, the focus is clearly more on the plot, which, in this case, does not help Ao no Exorcist`s case.  


That said, I continue to enjoy Ao no Exorcist--but only as a typical shounen anime.  It`s not bad by any means--but it just seems to fall short of the greatness it seemed to suggest in its first half.

This anime is a real „Cliche Anime“ (I use this term to describe anime shows that are usual examples given by people who don't understand anything about anime ex. Naruto, Death Note, Bleach...).
One Cliche Anime appeared in 2011 and with a total of 25 episodes it managed to get a rating of 8 on My Anime List.
May I present...Ae no Exorcist or better known as The Blue Exorcist
Plot and Storyline:
I read a couple of reviews on this anime and all the writers share one taught. This anime is just another shounen anime set in an ordinary school setting. But I don't think so. First ofall, a lot of people mix up the school setting where it would be unusual to have an exorcist class and those where that's not the case. In The Blue Exorcist the school is used just as a facade for the outside world as a cover for the „exorcist education“. I hope you get what I'm trying to say here. This is a very interesting storyline about a boy with demonic powers, his relationship with his brother and interaction between the human world-Assiah and the demon world-Gehenna. \n
The story begins 15 years ago when Satan, the god of demons, wants to take over Assiah. For that to work out he needs a human body powerful enough to contain him. For that reason he creates Rin and Yukio, his sons from a human woman. The only thing that didn't come to his mind was : "What if my sons don't want me? What if they don't become evil as I am?". Well, Mr.Satan, you should have thought about it earlier. \n
A good plot that didn't lack in action and background stories that really bring up some emotions.\n
Characters:\n
The characters in this anime really are something. The diversity of the personalities is incomparable. We have The determine class number 1 Kamiki, The lazy yet talented Rin, Konekomaru the cry-baby, The funny Shima, The family's prodigy Yukiro, the little daisy-girl Shiemi etc.\n
Still, the only character development occurs within Shiemi. She really developes from a naive little girl to a determine fighter and exorcist that despite everything doesn't lose her kindness and will to help others. A sunshine and optimist, round of applause for Shiemi. \n
However, my favorite character stays Rin, and not because he is the main character. I love him because he sometimes reminds me of my self. We both have potential and power but we are just too lazy and it is damn hard to motivate us. But when we actually find something we crave for than we'll gonna make it, no matter what.\n
Animation:\n
If I were to rate the animation and the looks of this anime I would definitely give it a 9/10. The characters look awesome, demons look also great, and the screen-diversity, Epic. Special commend goes to the look of the True Cross Academy. It surely is a little extra that makes you remember the story as a whole. \n
The only bad thing about this anime is the very end. The end idea was great, but the way it was brought over to the watcher was crappy. Why on Earth are laser-like beams doing in the gate between Assiah and Gehenna? Some of my friends think about it in the same way, I'll leave it to you to discover it.  \n
Conclusion:\n
Ae no Exorcist is indeed an anime I strongly recommend. With a low violence level it is suitable even for younger watchers, boys or girls. The anime is for me a 7/10. Minus points to the poor ending and lack of awesome fights. There was action but I definitely excepted more from a sword carrying half-demon. Furthermore I'd like to mention the unfinished love story, not fair at all.\n
On the whole, this anime is in fact worth the time. It is another yet different demon story that despite some lacks streams the way into your heart and stays there for some time.

He enrolled in an academy where his tutor is his own younger twin brother. Helping humankind was nvr this fun~

This show wasn't too bad. I watched it when I was a kid and I enjoyed it to the fullest, but since I'm a bit older I can say for an older audience this might not be the show for you. Did I enjoy the show, somewhat yes, but the shows enjoyment level was like a roller coaster for me. The show had it's really fun times, then it had its pretty bland and lame times. The beginning of the show is what made me want to watch it til the end, because that beginning was truly just too epic. Although the beginning was grand,the middle part was alright, and the end was kinda a let down. There were too many convenient factors in the show, which made me question some parts of the show. I also didn't really like the side characters, they were strange and unfitting. 


Story:

Now the story is pretty cool, it's about a boy who has inherited the powers of Satan by unsheathing a sword which has contained his powers. With his new powers and with his cool new sword, he wishes to defeat Satan and bring piece to Earth. Along side with his powers he trains to be an exorcist, but he must keep his powers hidden so his classmates, so they won't know his relation to the evil ruler of the underworld. This story sounds pretty cool, and the beginning was amazing, but after the whole fireworks display of a opening for a show, the glamour of the show declines as he "trains". 


Characters:

The characters are alright, they all seem to have no other characteristics besides the ones they were assigned. The angry dude is always angry, the quiet one is always quiet, things like that. Then there are the side characters, the 'comic relief' that this show tried to offer. They aren't funny, and they are more annoying than anything. Then the brother character, he was a little annoying because of how many things they tried to role into one character. They tried a little too hard with him, and not any of the other characters. Overall if you have a favorite character, you'll end up not really liking the other ones as much because their personalities almost never change.


Art:

Nothing much here. There were some cool affects here and there, some detail was good, but other than that just standard art styles. The music was bad, except for the first opening song, that song was good.


Overall, it was fun rewatching this show, but I probably wouldn't watch it again. I enjoyed it as a kid so that's the important part, since this show is for kids.


Pros; Good first anime, cool story, some nice action scenes

Cons; Not for an older audience, convenience in some scenes

Overall not as good as I hoped it to be but still worth the watch. It's very classic shonen. The story was pretty lacklustre in the end and despite having a lot of potential it didn't do anything interesting at all. Characters received very little to no development and were either illogically set in the ideals or annoyingly fickle with little middle ground. The best character in Shiro Fujimoto was unfortunately only in it for about 2 episodes with a few cameos later on too.
The biggest failure for me though is the motivations for pretty much all the characters in the show. The entire castof protagonists motivations can be boiled down to getting stronger to "protecting my friends" / "get revenge on Satan". Takara was the most interesting character in this respect because we're still in the dark on him. He has a small but cool scene where he was just watching the fighting and quoting some lines from mythology or something. The way he acts throughout is as if he is far stronger and knows far more than he lets on. Mephisto I think is equally as good, basically acting as the Izaya Orihara of Blue Exorcist. Although far less in the shadows than Takara, its clear there's more to him and what he wants than just playing games with people.


The bad guys were even worse though. All the demons just fight or mess with people because hey they're demons it's what they do. Ernst came out of nowhere by suddenly seizing the entire Vatican totally inexplicably and somehow convinced all the exorcists that opening the gate to gehenna was in any way a good idea. Earlier on they even admitted that they had no way of fighting back against Satan which was the whole reason they let Rin stay alive and then they decide to go and sacrifice him to get to Satan. Sure they had the Messiah bomb but it was never shown that they tested it to check it's efficacy and guess what, it ended up doing fuck all. They tried to give Satan something by having his motivations come from Yuri who is this lovable person that's get wrongly persecuted. Which could've worked great by making us understand his side of just trying to bring the two worlds together but then he continues to act like a complete dickhead and attempts destroys the city.


On to some of the good. It was generally pretty well animated and the fight choreography wasn't too bad but the attacks and power ups did get a little samey. Voice acting gets no complaints and I liked the music during the show overall. The OP and ED were more than skippable though. The character interactions between the students specifically were well done and I got a few laughs throughout. Also the part with Blackie was done well enough to work a tear or two down my face, although that's maybe not saying much considering my disposition to cry rather easily.

Blue Exorcist has a soft spot with me, mainly because it was the second anime I watched fully, which was about almost 2 years ago now. I wanted to rewatch this when the second season came out, but I got sidetracked by other things and I thought I'll rewatch it now when I had time. Even after 2 years it's still a great anime.
Story (9/10)
The story concentrates on Rin Okumura, a half human and half demon who turns out to be the son of Satan, along with his brother Yukio he trains at True Cross Academy to become an Exorcist to kick Satan'sass.

The story is really simple, boy/girl has an unnatural power and they train to use this power for a certain goal aka kicking Satan's ass, but what I really love about the story is how progressive it is. It goes at a very decent pace with Rin discovering his powers and then learning how to use them along with learning the ways of an Exorcist with his other classmates, while also keeping his Demon side a secret.

The first half of the series is pretty slow, but each of the episodes were really fun to watch as we see Rin and the others develop as Exorcists and characters, which is what I like since most series that have a large cast of characters usually have the supporting characters in the background, yet Blue Exorcist tries to make sure most of the characters get a chance to shine.

The second half of the series is where the situation gets a lot more serious, episodes 13-17 are the episodes that still connect with the manga (I'll get to that in a minute). These bunch of episodes were really well done as we see Rin and the others have a camping trip mission that shows how well they can work together, but also a huge plot point happens where Rin finally exposes his demon powers to the others.

Episodes 18-25 are episodes where the series diverges from the manga and usually this ends up being a very bad move for most anime's "cough" Tokyo Ghoul "cough", but Blue Exorcist manages to make it work in some way. We see Rin having to gain the trust of his friends once more as they now see him for what he truly is and some of Rins friends are truly tested with how they feel about him.

The final episodes have Yukio dragged into a plot by the Vatican where they are planning to wipe the Demons off the planet and launch a missile to destroy Hell. Rin ends up being used for this and Yukio breaks into a rage that manages to bring Satan through and for a final confrontation this was pretty good, not brilliant, but still good and the series ended in a satisfying way. The only reason why I won't give the story a 10 despite it being really fun and entertaining, the diversion from the manga does hurt it a little and even if it was a good diversion it's not something to be praised.


Characters (9/10)


Most of the characters in this show are absolutely great, despite a huge number of characters each one manages to shine in their own way that makes them very interesting.


Rin Okumura is honestly my favourite male character in anime, you can hate me, but he's awesome. Rin is quite different from you're usual Shounen protagonist, true he has the normal loud scream and can be pretty damn angry like most Shounen MC's, however he's actually more restrictive with his anger than I originally realised and he can be a very funny and clumsy guy mostly, making him an instantly likeable character. He also isn't overpowered when using his demon powers, he can easily beat small fry demons, but he can have a hard time taking them down and most of the time needs help from the others, but when he loses control you better stay away from him. He's also immensely protective of his friends wanting to make sure he uses his powers for good and to make sure he would never harm anyone close to him, plus he's a great cook too.

Yukio Okumura is Rin's twin brother and despite being younger than Rin he is actually more mature than him and is a teacher at the academy. He's strict and formal, yet he does this to protect his students and Rin, he can be a badass when it comes to fighting with dual wielding pistols, which is always fun to see. He and Rin always butt heads with each other because they can never come to an agreement, but they never lost sight of their bond as brothers.

Shiemi Moriyama is the female MC and is a gardener of her mothers shop and a tamer at the academy. Shiemi is absolutely adorable, despite being clumsy and not being used to a social life, she's always a positive person and wants to make sure everyone is safe and happy including Rin, despite not much of a fighter she's very handy in battle when it comes to supporting the team as a medic with her extensive knowledge of herbs. Her fun personality just makes her a constant ray of sunshine whenever you see her.

Ryuuji or Bon, Renzou and Konekomaru are a trio of friends, who lost their families to Satan's blue flames. Bon has a bumpy relationship with Rin as he usually gets annoyed at his lack of concentration in class, but the two do form a close relationship over time. Renzou is you're typical ladies man and has a fear of bugs, but he is willing to help his friends whenever he can and Konekomaru is the brainy guy who offers a lot of knowledge on Demons and their powers. These guys work really well together and even though their relationship with Rin was tested when they found out he was a demon, they eventually stood by his side once more in the end.

Izumo Kamiki is your typical Tsundere, however despite being a bit of a bit*h she isn't entirely dislikeable and has some moments showing her soft side making her seem like she isn't always a pain in the ass.

Shura and Mephisto are the two higher up characters at the academy, Shura used to be a student under Rin and Yukio's adopted father and is a friggin badass with a sword, even though she does look like a discount Yoko from Gurren Lagann. She can be a really fun character though. Mephisto is the headmaster of the academy and is actually another son of Satan, he is a very random guy. His excessive clothes and personality make him a really funny guy, yet he also has a scheming side and even though he's training Rin to be a weapon against Satan, I have this sneaking suspicion that isn't the true case here.


Art (9/10)


The artstyle in this anime was actually pretty good, the academy looks really incredible with the different types of buildings all put together like a weird puzzle. I also really like how detailed each of the characters are showing how diverse the cast is and that they each stand out in making them recognisable whenever you see them, especially Mephisto and Shura. Plus the design of the Demons and monsters look pretty cool as well. 

The only downside to this is the CGI, luckily the CGI wasn't that much of a concentration in the entirety of the series and was only used in small snippets and luckily wasn't used for the demons and monsters, but the gate to hell looked pretty damn bad I'm going to admit that and really stops the artstyle from getting a 10.

I also liked the uniforms, weapons and powers the Exorcists used, it looked really awesome and showed how powerful of an organisation they were.


Sound (9/10)


What Blue Exorcist did really well was the op's, I liked both the first and second op's they had a badass beat to them and really fitted with the image of Rin's demon powers. The ed's is a different story, the first ed was actually pretty good and I liked how it traversed the academy with the characters dancing to the music, but the second one was pretty meh, I skipped it after listening to it the first time and never bothered with it afterwards.

The soundtrack was definitely good, it had a great mixture when it came to action moments and made the scenes feel really intense.


Extras:


As Action comes this had some pretty damn good action and it was nicely spaced out in the series, it wasn't a constant thing and had some episodes concentrate more on comedy than action. It was always fun seeing the characters kicking ass against Demons and finding ways of defeating them, since there are many different types of demons that require different ways of defeating them.

The comedy in this show was really good, it was always fun seeing Rin getting into clumsy situations and mocking his brother from time to time and his clumsiness was also a good source of laughs too.

There's also a little bit of a romance plot there too, although it's more of a love triangle between Rin, Shiemi and Yukio. However this isn't really that big in the whole series and only touches on it quite rarely, but whenever it does it can be cute with the scenes that have Rin and Shiemi together.


Enjoyment (9/10)


Overall (9/10)


Overall this is a very fun and entertaining series and will always be a nostalgic anime for me, since it was the second one I watched fully and had a huge cast of characters to make it such an enjoyable anime to watch.

I was knitting while watching the second half of this show. Which was on subs by the way. I was hardly paying attention, thats the only way I got through this. 
Its an understatement that I was disappointed I didn’t like this more. To be honest, it’s not about the popularity of the show, as if the hype ruined expectations, but because of the main character himself. 
I’ll explain. 
Rin and Yukio are twin brothers, and the sons of Satan. Alright, already interested. 
Rin is rebellious but also sweet and sensitive to others’ plights. BOOM, I love his clashing personality already. I’m sold everyone, letshop on the bandwagon. Yukio is the opposite, serious and sticks to the rules. The trope is there, all you need is the execution and these brothers should carry the show on their shoulders right? 


No, no it did not happen. 


I didn’t like Yukio until the last episode. He was mysterious, condescending, jealous, uptight, overprotective in a twisted way and the show decided to justify him AT THE VERY END. In a way, this approach to his character was smart as it creates tension for the upcoming plot, but if I just dislike him and he takes up half of the screen time as a main character, it’s just not going to sell.


Now Rin. I. Love. Rin. I loved him so much I was imagining him being in any other show, without a brother, and different circumstances to make for a better experience. There were so many ways to sympathize and adore him, even though he falls into the “woe is me, tragic backstory but super powerful and will save the world” trope. Which, again makes me realize why they wanted that twin brother, to add an interesting conversation of this contrasting sibling with similar circumstances but different approach. Them being siblings makes this show different and great, I must say, but god dammit it was tedious execution.((AT THE END OF THE SHOW, I REALLY APPRECIATED THAT. HONESTLY. BUT I DISLIKED ALL THE EPISODES LEADING TO IT THAT I HAVE TO GIVE A LOWER REVIEW. IM SORRY))


So Yukio didn’t ruin the whole show by himself, I would never drop a show based on one character unless that character had all the screen time. This show has many side characters— mainly being the classmates in their special demon hunting school. 


Generally, the classmates were fine. They had cute moments, funny dialogue on occasion, and fine backstories. Their designs were nice, but I didn’t click with any of them. Perhaps, as students, I never felt the dire tension of their arcs? For Rin, it always felt dire because of his growing power and being in an unfamiliar situation where he has to make friends, without revealing his nature, and actually attempts to study. For the students, their pasts with demons are haunting them to move become hunters but the way its presented in the show feels abstract. I forgot a lot of the first half of the show, I apologize, but it shows I didn’t find the impact of their tragic past a reason to sympathize with them— which is more of a fault with the storyboarding of the episodes. 


As individual episodes go, as I’ve made clear, any that focused purely on Rin’s arc, I enjoyed. There are episodes focused on the classmates and I blanked out on those, not finding them too important. Also once you get to the end of the series, the only reason those character are focused on is to create a familial bond to boost the positive outlook on the main characters. I didn’t need entire episodes for that; it doesn’t take long to like a character. If you need an entire episode to like a character, they need to be a complicated piece of work that makes you think, “they're worth it” at the end. 


The Father, Satan, and the mom are also characters I liked but its not like they were shown often. A damn shame. 


Other random comments, the placement of the music in the show was nice and the action scenes were very fun to watch. I remember watching a scene that blasted the music during a certain camera angle and thought, “I would think this is so badass, if I didn’t care so little.”


I didn’t expect to write this so sorry if the review is all over the place, but I had to air my frustrations. 


Give me the character Rin, make an entire new show around him, and I’ll eat it up. Honestly, he was the only reason I finished it.

Since I've read the manga I fell for it, so, if it wasn't for the manga, I don't know if this anime would deserve more than an 8. Besides, I don't know if someone that did not read the manga is capable to talk about the characters or story, cause they get much more interesting after the anime's end. I can't say if it is a "classical Shounen" cause I did not like the other Shounens I've watched and always thought they were boring and repetitive, which makes me unable to compare (respect it, I just have no patience to see 400 to 600 episodesof a story that focus on fights and have lots of fillers and others useless chapters that are forgotten as the story goes on). If someday I watch Naruto, that looks really nice, I can think about Ao no Exorcist being cliche or not.


Story 7 of 10:

Ao no Exorcist is the first anime I've saw that focus on exorcists, but that's not important. The autor somewhat mixed real life and its beliefs (Vaticano, Illuminati) and her fiction on the story, and some of this fiction is also inspired in real life beliefs (Satan) what I thought that was very interesting. And Gehenna and Assiah, the both worlds presents in the story, are not names picked up from nowhere. Gehenna is a small valley in Jerusalem which is the Jewish and Christian analogue of hell, and Assiah is the region where the Ofanim rule and where they promote the hearing of prayers, support human endeavor, and combat evil. Even if I'm the only stupid that didn't notice it in the same second, I got really excited with the idea of using something like that in the story, cause it somewhat make it looks like the story could really be true (I don't think it is but... you got it). Ao no Exorcist is a lot more complex than it looks like. Actually, I just didn't gave it a 10 because I know that exists better storys. But, if it's like that, why did I gave a 7? That's cause, after half of the anime they changed completely the course of the story and it became shit. I wouldn't recommend this anime from the half on, but they are now making an second season that ignores the invented half of the first season and follow correctly the manga, which deserves a 9 in the plot. So, if you ever watch Ao no Exorcist, stop at the 15 episode and jump for the second season. The story is also really funny (if you don't laugh at chapter 65 in the manga it has something wrong with you).


Art 7 of 10:

Just like the story, the art of the anime is worst than the art of the manga, but that's cause the animation wasn't really well made. You can notice that they sometimes use some artifacts to hide the bad animation but that doesn't work, and its not really fluid or consistent, but not so bad that you can't stand it. Is possible to ignore the bad art (which isn't exactly terrible, its enjoyable and have its moments) and it keeps being better than lots of other Shounen, whose animation really collaborate for me to not want to see the anime. But this so-so quality doesn't get worse in the battle scenes. Actually, I think it gets better. In the manga, what piss of sometimes is that the artist can't always finish drawing in time and lots of pages get an art obviously incomplete, but I think that just happen 2 or 3 times, and in a manga with almost  90 chapters that's not really much. 


Sound 8 of 10:

I didn't disliked the voice of the characters. Actually, I liked them very much, mostly Rin's voice, that I think it really suited him. Even the characters that have accent can dub very well and the voice doesn't piss me off like in some animes, where I really want to turn the sound off. But the anime lose points in the openings and endings, that aren't very interesting and give a wish to jump them and just go to the story. I usually don't pay attention to the background music, but when they are bad I usually notice. Since I didn't noticed anything strange or boring about the anime sounds I think they were at least acceptable. 


Characters 10 of 10:

I just have fallen in love with basically all of the characters. Though you can't notice in the anime only, in the manga they get really complex. Sometimes you don't know if the character is a hero or a villain, they not always make the right decisions and that make you simpatize with them. I'm not gonna tell how that happens, but some characters that really surprise you with time are Izumo, Shima (MY FUCKING GOD, this guy really surprised me! You will know why if you read the manga) and, unexpectedly, Shiemi (yeah, she's more strong than she looks like). Ryuuji take a little more time, but he surprises you too. You will never understand Mephisto and, until now, I don't know if Yukio is a nice guy or if he's gonna surprise me and become a bad guy. Every time I look at him I imagine him becoming a villain. I think the strong point of Ao no Exorcist is how all the characters learn more about themselves and become better with time, not only in power but psychologically talking as well. In the most part of the animes I watched the characters were always good since the beginning and just were misunderstood. The coolest part is that not always they become better, some of them become worst as well, like they discover a new part of themselves and, even if that means betray they friends, give up their pride or stand up to they parents/responsibles, they're gonna make it in favor to do what they want to do. The relationship between the brothers (Yukio and Rin) is really interesting as well. Yukio envy the charisma of Rin, the way he inherited the father's flames, got protected by everyone and was treated as someone special, but Rin envy the way Yukio is strong and intelligent, got the chance to train side by side with Shiro and saw him show his power. The most cliche about the characters is Shiemi's stupid kindness and Rin's stupid optimism, but with time they get more complex and interesting and, if you wanna know, I wouldn't change Rin's personality never in my life, he's just too cute, I wanted to bite him and hug him 'till he begs for air. His smile is just perfect as well. And I think his ability of cooking is really creative.


Enjoyment 10 of 10: 

What can I say? I couldn't sleep because I wanted to get done watching first. When I started the manga it was almost impossible for me to stop and I got surprised all the time. I know that not everybody is gonna like Ao no Exorcist, but I have to at least make my part and recommend it for you. But I recommend specially de manga and, if you are the type that just watch anime you probably won't notice all the perfection I described here. But if you already saw the anime, don't worry, that won't get in the way if you want to try the manga. Actually, I think is nice to compare the both. 


Overall 8 of 10: 

Anime:  (7 + 7 + 8 + 10 + 10) / 5 = 8.4

Manga: (9 + 8 + ? + 10 + 10) / 4 = 9.25

This review contains spoiler! 
Story 6/10:
Ao no Exorcist indeed deserves its popularity. It has the potential to continue its quality. However, the story remained very one dimentional.
Demons in this anime portray a very interesting role, taking on both the  part of traditional images of demons and gods. The idea of depicting demons as ancient forms with a curious mind is a very good idea. They needn't to be sympathized with, nor understood. In some way, they lack complex thinking, but are more powerful than humans. This make them decide very easily rights and wrongs as though their first experience in assiah. Those whose actionhasn't been denied by humans continues to help and protect humans, the others turn "evil" and take revenge on humans.

This way of representing mythical power and forms is in some way very accurate. As Rin said in the end, humans have to hear the voices of these demons. Demons are not a kind destined to be hated or loved. The point of their appearance on earth is to integrate in Assiah and be accepted by humans. 

Nonetheless, this anime failed to display the one thing it is suppose show: make them listen to eachother. Throughout the entire show, there is not a moment where one message is successfully passed on. The people are either yelling, being stubborn, too lazy to explain, or successful in solving the problem by shouting a few short sentences which missed a whole lot of informations. In the end, right after Rin said his sentence (the one above), he took out a sword and is ready to knock the demon unconscious. The most irritating part is the false message passed around the main family. Yuri's (Rin and Yukio's mother) message to Satan is misunderstood. When she said she wanted a world with demons and humans, she meant an integration, not a destruction-filled takeover. Satan's (Rin and Yukio's biological father) message to his sons is misunderstood. He wanted to complete the world their mother wished, not distroy Assiah. Yukio, receiving the memessage did not care about it's contents. He and his brother Rin then slashed the gate of Gehenna and shouted to their father: we don't care about your reason, we just care about our situation.

Yes, so much for listening. 


The ending felt a tiny bit rushed. There are less dramatical pauses than other animes. Although it is not a huge problem once you get used to it. 


This show really is something to look forward to, but is flawed with communication problems, making it - fair(6).


Art 9/10:

The art is quite unique, and captivating. The characters do not have giraffe necks and googly eyes. The movements are fluid and the color fits very well with the theme.


Sounds 8/10:

The seiyuus are very good. Their voices really matched the characters, or their coices brought the characters to life. The background music, however, doesn't fit sometimes. The hype is way to high sometimes for certain scenes. It's a relief that it only happens once in a while.

The opening and endings are all great. The production team chose them well.

All together, the sound is very good(8).


Characters 5/10:

Communication problem, disability, makes reader fustrated

As pointed out before, the characters are reluctant to listen to eachother. There are a lot of shouting consisting of short sentences, which is then followed by silence or a loud (also short) response, or useless happy talks. When the problem is magically solved without real exchange between the characters, it is just frustrating. This really makes one wonder if they have communication disabilities.

If not for this big dent in their design, the characters are quite likable. I hope the sequel improves on this.

You know how sometimes a shounen with a ton of tropes can be just the worst thing ever? Yeah... this is the exact opposite of that. This anime is one of the reasons why tropes got to be so common; everything about it just works.
