Blue Exorcist is focused on Rin Okamura, a teenage boy who is a half-demon born between his human mother and the demon Satan. With the death of his adoptive father, Rin seeks to become an exorcist to slay his father and any demons that threaten humanity.
At a glance, Blue Exorcist doesn't really break any new ground for a shounen series and it certainly shows with its premise. An action-loving young boy outcast from others due to differences in his origins seeking to prove his worth through hard work and perseverance has been hammered out a good deal with a number of other similar titles likeNaruto and Black Clover. The characters found within the series are also nothing groundbreaking either as many sport character types you may have come across in one form or another from other anime titles as well. The plot is also nothing spectacular with a school devoted to training exorcists and some "demon of the day" episodes or arcs have something similar found in other anime as well.


Still, the series seems to have a good sense of what it is and chooses to just go along what it offers up. It offers a solid amount of world-building to introduce the major elements of its series involving exorcists and demons without being too focused on its action. The characters, in spite of their archetypes, get a good deal of dimension to show there is more to them and are rather likeable as the series doesn't exaggerate their character types to obnoxious levels as titles like Naruto often got in the annoying habit of. The plot of the series juggles the mundane days of Rin's interactions with the student body of True Cross Academy, while dispatching any demonic threats without revealing his demon origins to others. While the first half of the series sticks with this storytelling approach, there are some engaging developments for the show's middle section that test Rin's bonds with his classmates and other exorcists start to view Rin as a possible threat. It also doesn't hurt that the series is nicely animated sporting character designs with a good amount of detail, vivid scenery shots, and fluid battle scenes that play out.


The series does gradually slip up toward its final episodes. As the manga this series was still ongoing (and still is as of this review), the show's creators winded up creating anime-only original plot developments that explore how Satan and Rin's mother birthed our lead character and a grand finale that attempts to tie up loose ends with the conflict between demons and human exorcists. However, this still left the series open-ended with the conflict still ongoing. Matter of fact, the later plot developments of this series were totally disregarded for its later sequel, Blue Exorcist: Kyoto Saga.


While nothing groundbreaking, Blue Exorcist still makes for solid entertainment with its world exploration and focus on Rin dealing with his demon origins while bonding with the teenage exorcists of Blue Cross Academy. In spite of its anime-original developments towards its second half, I would still say it is at least worth a single viewing for fantasy-adventure anime fans to check out.

I'm dropping this anime so this is just a short review, mostly for me, so that I can memorialize my thoughts. Maybe I will continue watching this someday, but I don't think that will be the case. 
I'm 11 episodes in and, although I won't pretend to be an expert on the show, around 4 hours of a good show should provide something to give the audience a reason to continue watching. This show just didn't do it for me. 
The show has a lot of things that are reasonable in a vacuum, but just don't make sense in the context of the show. Basically,in every aspect of the show, there is no element which answers "Is this a show I should continue watching?" positively. I'll run it down.




Story: 4


The show is very episodic. There's nothing wrong with that generally, it works to great effect in tons of shows. However, it is absolutely non-traditional for the genre. A lot of mediocre adventure/action/angst anime are held together solely by the promise of a climactic plot structure. ANE may have that in the end, but I can't see any sign of it. There are certainly signals that -something- is happening in the background, but I'm halfway through the series and I don't really have a sense of what that is at all. 


Good episodic series succeed because they execute well within each episode. That means they must have something that entertains the audience. But it doesn't. More on that later.




Art: 8


OK. The art isn't bad at all. A 7 at worst. It is certainly stylistically uninspired and the character design isn't super engaging, but generally, everything is well-drawn. Even the CGI is done pretty decently. However, since it is uninspired, the art won't be the reason you watch it. This is the anime review zone. You're not going to watch an anime 'because it looks like anime'.




Sound: 5


The sound isn't bad in a vacuum. The tracks are actually stylistically sort of neat. However, they don't make any sense in the context of the show. Nothing else about this show is stylistically inspired or gives a hint that these are the sorts of tracks that should be playing. Often times the tracks just evoke the improper emotional response for the situation as well. 


The voice acting is also annoying. All lines seem forced and angsty. It's not natural. I can't blame sound entirely for that though.




Character: 3


All the characters are bad. No exceptions. The crux of the problem is just in how they act. Forget the backstory. Really, there are only 2 notable states for the main group of characters, super angsty or hyper-emotional. It's not realistic at all. There is no character I can think of that has any positive, relatable traits. It seems that way because, whenever the characters are not in this state, they fail at imitating normal human behavior. Nearly all attempts at humor fail. There is never and subtlety or semblance of delicacy with how the series handles human interactions. Everyone takes their turns for their lines and the all feel so forced. Nobody has anything interesting to say, ever. Don't watch this show if you care about characters.




Enjoyment: 3


Obviously, so far there is nothing worth enjoying. It could have bad animation or sound and be worse, but whatever. Something that can normally save these types of series would be good action. ANE have simply OK action, and it isn't happening often enough. It isn't enough to make you want to watch. 


Just to reiterate, each of these things alone is not good enough for you to want to watch the show: art, world building, sound, characters, plot, action, humor. What else could a series like this have to offer?




Overall: 4


4 seems like the appropriate number, but my experience with the show thus far has been mostly negative, and MAL calls 4 decent. A 3 at worst. If somebody talks me into watching the whole show for whatever reason, I could continue. But this is where I end for now.

***** SPOILER FREE *****
In order for an anime to be successful in my eyes, it has to meet three criteria:
1) Compelling Story
2) Strong Character Development
3) High Overall Entertainment Factor
An anime should be created in the order of 1-3. Skipping around will leave other criteria lacking. Once all three of these points have been met, an anime will leave the viewer satisfied and fulfilled for spending eight hours of their life in front of a computer screen. 
Ao no Exorcist fails at all three of these points.
--- Story (2/10) ---
The synopsis for this anime is written at the top of this screen. What I am writinghere is very brief. Rin Okumura and Yukio Okumura are the spawns (sons) of Satan, but only Rin has awakened his demonic powers. This alone was what sold me.When I watched the first episode, I was immediately hooked and was curious as to how the story would unfold. It's a shame that episode 1 was the only good episode in the entire show. When a story unfolds, a crucial element is the problem the characters are tasked with solving. Rin is faced with the task of defeating Satan (for reasons explained in episodes 1 and 2), the only problem is his lack of control over his power and his unbelievable stupidity. If a character is faced with such a daunting obstacle, the story has to keep a decently fast pace in order to show the development of the main character. The pace for Ao no Exorcist is UNGODLY slow. Why should Rin go to a school for exorcists when he has no skill in exorcism? Why didn't he learn to control his powers since episode 2 instead of waiting until the climax? Why was Mephisto (a demon) not overseeing the development of Rin if he was his godfather? Why is Rin soooo stupid? I get that ignorance from the main character is comical and serves an overall purpose, but Rin's IQ is less than 50 and pisses off the viewer more than entertaining the viewer. There are so many unanswered questions that make you wonder why certain plot lines were even explored. If a plot line is exposed, it better add to the depth of the story, otherwise it is a waste of time to introduce it. Ao no Exorcist leads the viewer away from the main path onto so many irrelevant bunny trails that it leaves you stranded in the middle of a forest wondering "What am I supposed to get out of this anime?"




--- Character Development (2/10) ---


Rin Okumara and Yukio Okumura are introduced as the lead characters, but the anime makes it especially clear that Rin is the MAIN character right off the bat. If the production team decided on Rin as the main character, then it would make sense that Rin should get the spotlight at the end of the show... right? Apparently, such a strain of thought is illogical, but hey, what do I know? I'm just here to criticize their failure.  


Shiro Fujimoto is the guardian for Rin and Yukio. He is probably the one character that served his purpose effectively. Without giving too much away, his life was what character development should have been. The viewer learns about Fujimoto through a handful of flashbacks that were scattered far and thin. My only criticism is that these flashbacks should have told more of his background due to the fact that he is a pivotal character in the story.


Shiemi Moriyama is Rin's crush, although his affections seem to fade.. Why? Who knows. She is one character that is very entertaining and shows the best development in the entire show. From shy and timid to outstanding and vocal about her opinions, she was truly the only character that was enjoyable. 


Ryuji Suguro, as well as some others, are Rin's classmates. My only quibble is that if a character has a foil, the foil should develop as fast or faster than the main character. Suguro is introduced as the foil to Rin, but it looks like the production team decided not to waste their time with him and transferred the role of foil to someone else. Make up your minds people!


Shura Kirigakure is an upper class exorcist that "trains" Rin. The word train is used very loosely as the only role she serves in this show is for fan service. 


Mephisto Pheles is one of the most enigmatic characters in the entire show. His motives are kept hidden from the viewer... for the entire show! Seriously, if you're going to introduce such an amazing character, at least have the courtesy to do him justice. It's such a shame that an incredible potential to better the story line is lost entirely. 


Kuro and Ukobach are two very cute characters (one being a talking cat, and the other a cooking imp). Too bad they were introduced and left to rot. The lack of attention to these characters annoys me to no end.The production team randomly gave, Kuro, the giant cat, the ability to fly in the middle of the last fight scene so as to allow the good guys to win. Why??    ¯\_(ツ)_/¯


SATAN is probably my favorite character in the entire show. You never see Satan, you only hear his voice. The voice of Satan is phenomenal. Saying anything more about him delves into spoiler territory. All I can say is that Satan is done justice. It is truly remarkable how characters that have less that 30 min of screen time tend to have the highest character development. 




--- Art (7/10) ---

The art design was decent. The transformation of Rin into a demon is very stereotypical, especially with the elf-ears, and doesn't provide the "awe" factor. I would expect some more thoughtful creations. The various demons that the characters encounter are somewhat creative. Nii was a smaller version of Cacturne. I don't understand how art can be so difficult to incorporate into a story. If the production team lacks art creativity, then the story should revolve around that aspect. It's like trying to make a science-fiction film with the budget of a romcom. It just won't work. Either increase your budget, or stop with those high aspirations. 




--- Sound Production (9/10) ---

The only reason this category got a 9 instead of a 10 is because I absolutely loathe the voicing of Rin Okumura in the english dub. It's the epitome of annoyance. Besides that, the sound production quality is exceptional. Hiroyuki Sawano is a musical genius. Absolutely brilliant background score. I loved it so much, I purchased the entire soundtrack. The first opening was catchy with the jazzy intro, but the second opening definitely stole the spotlight. Both endings were beautiful. It's a shame that such wonderful accompaniment is given to an undeserving show. 






--- The Final Verdict ---

Ao no Exorcist is an anime that had an excellent premise for a game changing show. There were so many instances where deep, thought provoking, philosophical themes could have been explored but where left to catch dust instead. The overall pace was pitifully slow. There were many times that I wanted to quite watching, but my OCD for leaving a show unfinished is what helped me get through it. An unnecessary amount of comic relief was used in areas of the story that were fine without it. I might have completely missed the point, but what I saw was a disgraceful excuse for an anime. Due to the PG-13 rating, I judge that this show was meant for children. If that's the case, efforts to include dark, spiritual content should be avoided entirely. If an anime decides to explore grim themes, it should fully commit, not make a half-assed attempt at a godforsaken excuse for entertainment. I really see no reason to recommend watching this show. If you are an audiophile, I recommend listening to the entire background score. Otherwise, only watch Ao no Exorcist for the sake of adding another anime to your list.

Ao no Exorcist is one of only a few anime out there that could have been quite good, but wasn't. In fact, given the material it's based on (well, for the most part), it absolutely should have been good. The problem is twofold: almost comically poor English voice acting and a terrible ending to the story. While it is certainly understandable to have a somewhat sub-par ending when, as in the case of Ao no Exorcist, the anime gets ahead of the manga from witch it is based, but the butchery that was committed in this case is frightening. Worth watching (in SUBS!!), but acolossal disappointment for those who follow the manga.

Ao No Exorcist. Wow. Where do I even begin? 
A long while ago, I discovered this anime through a blog I was reading, and decided to give it a go. I got to episode 7 of the anime, I think, but I got a bit bored of it by that point. At the time, I kind of limited myself to strictly non-shounen animes because I basically found the general idea of them to be unrealistic and crap. But, oh, how wrong I was. One thing that especially drew me in to Ao No Exorcist is the art. I love how clean and bright the art is in this anime- it's one of the nicest and sharpest I've seen thus far. Very easy viewing on the eyes.\n
Next, the voice actors. This is the first anime I've watched that only has the option of watching in Japanese with English subtitles, so I was a bit jubious from lack of experience. But the voices were fantastic, all fitted the characters imensly. My favourite is probably Yukio or Mephisto- their voice actors did such a good job. And Rin, naturally. Oh yes, Bon and Shima were awesome as well. \n
Story line! The slightly important part, might I add. (I'll try not to spoil anything.) Wow, just wow. The story line is, excuse my French, fucking amazing. Maybe I only think so because I've never watched a shounen before this one, but honestly. Even though I at first got bored, that never happened again. I was completely captivated by the storyline and characters, and I spent two whole evenings doing nothing but watching the episodes I had left on DVD. Slightly anti-social... I got so emotionally attatched to Rin and Yukio, that whilst watching the last episode I cried. Quite a bit, embarassingly enough. I'd better finish this here and not waste anymore of your time. My final verdict is a 9/10. Can't really fault it on much. I definitly recommend this to anyone, no matter what your taste in anime is. So, a show about somebody going after Satan and the person who wants vengeance happens to be his son? Well, of course this idea isn’t new but it’s something.
Humans live in the world of Assiah, demons in Gehenna. The two dimensions are not meant to interfere with each other, but demons still possess creatures in Assiah in spite of this. The humans who can fight these demons are known as exorcists. Rin Okumura is a boy who bears the curse of being Satan's illegitimate son. His foster father sacrificed himself to save him from demons. To avenge his foster father's death as well as toprove himself, Rin decides to follow the path of an exorcist.


It’s just not original which most people have been saying about this show, that is the same type of shounen series that all have seen before but does it mean that it’s terrible? Maybe to some, but it’s not about them. The story may have been done before but it did entertain me as it goes around.


That being said, the show does have a bit of religious tone and I am not a religious guy at all but it didn’t get too overbearingly religious as it’s also more like Hellboy in a way but let’s not get carried away.


For the characters, there is very cookie-cutter, run-of-the-mill characters in the show like Rin, who wants to overcome his chances of beating Satan but while training he’s all brawn and little brains, would charge into an attack without knowing a strategy but Rin can be a likable character and goofy in a good way into later episodes albeit he has to keep his secret hidden from mostly everyone. Yukio, Rin’s brother, does get more interesting as the show goes along as he never jokes or bullshit around about his studies of being an exorcist and I do like the relationship between Rin & Yukio as brothers as it wasn’t too feely-sappy but it wasn’t angsty as most people make it out to be. Two other interesting characters in the show are Mephisto Pheles, the Chairman of the True Cross Academy and he’s always bring his eccentric personality whenever he is on screen & Shiro Fujimoto, the foster father of Rin & Yukio and a priest at the Southern Cross Monastery and while this character was killed off in the second episode, he does appear in flashback sessions of the show that gets us to know him as a character. Other characters like Shiemi Moriyama, Izumo Kamiki, Ryuji Suguro, Renzo Shima, & Konekomaru Miwa are okay as well but they happen to be very stereotypical and run-of-the-mill character tropes like the forced romantic interest, tsundere, the rival kid who would turn to be a friend later on, the playboy & the smart kid, respectively and there’s Shura Kirigakure, an Upper First Class exorcist under the guidance of Shiro and she is mostly the fan service character of the show and honestly, it needed that.


For the animation, A-1 Pictures, the offshoot animation production company of Aniplex, did want most shounen shows can’t do well and that is make great fighting scenes in the animation and visuals itself. The art style is very much like Soul Eater in terms of the designs, especially the True Cross Academy outlook. The music was a bit okay with the first opening sequence "Core Pride" by UVERworld, that grew into me and the same can be said for the second OP "In My World" by ROOKiEZ is PUNK'D, but I liked the first theme more. For the ending themes, as much as the first ED "Take Off" by 2PM didn’t fit, I actually liked it (I don’t know why but I do) and the second ED "Wired Life" by Meisa Kuroki was more fitting with the tone of the show. The background music is very orchestral sounding in all the right places and it was remarkably decent.


For the Aniplex/Bang Zoom! Dub that debuted on Neon Alley, when it was announced that Bryce Papenbrook and Johnny Yong Bosch would portray the main characters, I initially thought Bosch would be Rin but I’m glad he was Yukio as Bosch in a reformed character like him would be better suited and not be type casted as much and Papenbrook was good as the character of Rin; Sam Riegel was excellent as Mephisto, Kirk Thornton as Shiro excelled at being a good father figure and character and as for Christine Marie Cabanos as Shiemi, while I dig her voice, it sometime becomes too panicky in a non-panicky situation. Kira Buckland as Izumo nailed it with the character’s bitchiness intact, Wendee Lee as Shura remind me a lot of Faye Valentine…..well, mostly in the sound of her voice and the way she dresses and Stephanie Sheh as a demon cat? That’s an automatic win for me.


FINAL VERDICT: Now this show isn’t groundbreaking or new, the execution was handled pretty well in my opinion. It’s not the best that can be offered in this genre but compared to stuff like Naruto & Bleach, this is a good choice but I will say that you should probably watch Soul Eater but I would recommend this series to you, too.

Ao no Exorcist is a great and very straightforward animation, and hands down one of the nicest ones I've watched about demons, and let me tell you: the Japanese love their demons, so they have more than enough shows to spare.  
Rin and Yukio Okumuro are orphaned twins raised at a monastery by a salty yet humorous priest. 
While Yukio is intelligent, hard-working, calculating, and reserved, his twin brother Rin is brash, head-strong, and outspoken. As fate would have it the two of them are the offspring of Satan himself, thus they must learn how to wield their power and use is for goodinstead of following the demonic foot-steps of their dad. 


In order to master their skills and learn how to use their power for good Rin and Yukio are shipped off to an exoricst school ran by none other than Mephistopheles. 


Along his way Rin meets fascinating fellow students who each - as usually is in anime and manga - have their own stories to tell and reasons that keep them motivated at perfecting their exorcist skills. 


From the beautiful animation to the killer soundtrack, Ao no Exorcist is a great anime, not to mention that it does have some very unexpected (sort of) plot twists. Keep in mind that with this little jem not everything is what it seems.

The characters are wonderful, and the situations they find themselves in can be cumbersome, but more often than not are resolved in the best of ways. Even the peaceful situations characters find themselves in are pleasing to watch. The art direction, and color pallets are down right delicious, and make you crave more. More so than anything else though, it doesn't fall to cliches unlike other anime.
It's nice that something that seemed unoriginal could become it's own entity.  The only thing that feels like it's missing is villain motivation. The villain isn't all that present and is more talked about, not seen. This makesthe enemy feel empty at times, but it is made up for toward the end.

Soundtrack: It's cool ...... But nothing to highlight.
Characters: They are cool, if you like them, especially with Rin, but I think some of them are there just to fill holes or to leave the work withmore characters.\n\n
Overall: It is a good anime for a beginner, it has a simple and nice storyline, it is that kind of shounen that normally follows its genre, but if you are VERY rigid, you probably do not like it very much because it is a little predictable, If u like me like shounen if depending on being spontaneous or not, you will like it.

Ao no Exorcist is very biblical, it involves exorcists who fight against demons. The biggest demon of them all is of course Satan and the story revolves around his sons, Rin and Yukio Okumura. Rin seems to cause trouble everywhere he goes and lacks ambition while Yukio is more responsible and unlike Rin, knows the existence of demons and exorcist and has trained to become an exorcist since he was 7. Rin discovers that he has Satan's demonic powers and with the help of Mephisto Pheles, attends True Cross Academy with Yukio in order to become an exorcist and fight his father, Satan. 
The storyis pretty fast paced, which I do like, it doesn't linger on certain conflicts over multiple episodes and plot points throughout the series do end up mattering in the end. There are some holes and unanswered questions but nothing that can't be answered in the next season. The action is exciting to watch as Rin can't use his sword or else he will expose his demonic power to everyone. Though when he does use his sword, nothing can stop him. The blue flames look pretty damn cool too. 


The characters themselves are very entertaining, the comedy is really fun to watch when character clash with each other. I can't say I really disliked any of the characters in the series, as they were all really enjoyable to watch, except maybe the kid with the sock puppet, I don't know what his deal is and his mysteriousness intrigues me. Shiemi is definitely my favorite character though, Rin is a close second.


Overall, this is a series about exorcists, demons and it involves a lot of biblical references. The series doesn't take itself too seriously and by no means does it make fun of church and religion. It is a very entertaining and interesting anime and I really enjoyed myself. Action, comedy and supernatural demonic beings.

Blue Exorcist is, by my own standards, a modern classic anime. Incorporating all of the elements that make anime so expressive of human thought, this show not only has a solid plot, but an entertaining animation style with excellent development, even in the lonesome filler episodes. 
The main character has very similar qualities to the infamous Naruto, taking the risk of leaving the anime in the hands of a boisterous and obnoxious character to carry the show. Yet the series excels at focusing on a number of other characters as well, creating a well-rounded selection of individuals to captivate watchers into a shounen supernatural. 
Thecreative labour put into each character is one of the show's more notable qualities, making it difficult not to grow attached to the individuals that spark your preference in terms of personality. \n
In terms of scripting, the simple-minded comedy makes it a casual watch, although moments are carefully placed throughout the arcs to grapple your emotions to heights of anger and sadness as well.\n
Slightly relevant in addition, is that the English dub is not a horrible job, which is a common complaint in revoiced animes. Although the English voices don't quite capture the charm of the original voiceover, I hold this show as one of my personal favorites with it's simple charisma and amusing story.

So, I have been dying to write a review and flex my writing muscles, so that I can find a good way to make up for not having English class (Which I sorely miss), and what better way to do it than by writing a review of Blue Exorcist.
Story - 5 - Now the story, if you read about it already, it looks pretty genuine. It would've helped if the protagonist's father's name was NOT Satan, and could've been Ifrit (Which, mind you, also has a demonic background and sounds way more badass), because that's what struck me a lot. OH LORD, our hero isthe spawn of SATAN. Let's throw in a bat so we can shoe-horn in an Ace Ventura joke.

BEGONE! WINGED SPAWN OF SATAN!!!! - Never gets old. :-))

Okay, let's give it the benefit of the doubt that, Satan is not OUR Satan, but that does not change how generic and predictable the plot is. No, SERIOUSLY, IF I gave you the spoilers, you won't be surprised. TRUST ME! I mean the series was SO forgettable, that I only remember the important plot lines and forgot the fillers. OH YES, there's fillers, but it's only for one episode yet it serves no purpose to further the plot.


Art - 7 - Now I have to admit, the artwork is pretty good. The school looks breath-taking and the character designs, while some awkward, is pretty good. Heck! Why don't I enroll into True Cross Academy and learn how to summon Ifrit, OR #@$*!&% BAHAMUT! I mean, the classroom looks pretty well drawn. And never has a Principal's office looked so good. And good lord, THE BLUE FLAMES, they looked so gorgeous, yet so dangerous, That I want one of these for my screensavers. PERIOD!


Sound - 7 - The openings are #@$*!&% awesome. Not kidding, it has to be one of the most awesome OPs I've ever heard. If only the series stayed true to that. As for the OST, well, the series was so forgettable that even the OST is forgotten!!

As for the Anime Voices, I watched it in dub, and I have to give the crew some credit, they did it pretty well, especially with Johny Yong Bosch voice acting as Rin's brother, Yukio. And Rin's voice actor did a pretty good jod of capturing the spirit of a young, confident, hard-headed (is that even a word?) protagonist, that you can't help but love the guy. Can't judge the subs, but I can tell that the subbed works for some scenes in the anime than the dubs, especially in the summoning sequences.


Character - 6 -  Now let's get to, what may be the first time I have seen good characters get bogged down by a weak story. Rin makes for a pretty badass protagonist, who looked is down upon society. Yukio..........umm, he's a good brother, so there's that. And everyone else is genuinely, hmm how do I say this, basically riddled in anime tropes, except for Bon, even HE is not safe. The story and the characters are so cliched, that you can play 'Anime Trope Bingo'! 

(1st Prize - A body pillow of your favourite Waifu/Husbando / An illegal copy of that one episode of your favourite anime that isn't released yet!

Last Prize - THIS ANIME >:-(()

The character lacks substance, hence they are less memorable. Even with their own character arc, NOTHING can save them.


Enjoyment - 4 - Guys, It's basically a poor man's Soul Eater. You can tell by just looking at it. And like I said, FORGETTABLE.


Overall - 6 - The anime had great potential, but tripped harder than a school girl falling on a guy, with no pants on! (Who would forget THAT?!?!). In my opinion, GO WATCH SOUL EATER!!!! It's considered one of the best Shounen anime to hit the screen and has excellent art direction and OST, and the opening is helluva lot better, since the tone match so well with the show. This...is a sluggish train wreck. You sit down and the ride looks pretty pleasant, but by the time you realize it, BOOM! You are now suffering a slow and painful death, and you're begging someone would clobber you with an Asuka body pillow and then smother you to death, and what are your chances of encountering THAT. It's a bad way to go.

But at least the OP is badass!

The absolute dominant reason that Blue Exorcist sticks out amongst other anime is because it succinctly captures all the core aspects of a good show in around 25 episodes. It deserves a watch (not to mention that it is also on Netflix). The overall anime is solid - no question about that. Blue Exorcist ties together lots of unique elements into a neat story: religion, magic, ostracized youth, etc. The show is almost like a combination of Naruto and … Harry Potter. If that sounds really intriguing—good! Then this show is probably for you. 
One element that stood out to me in particular is brotherlylove - especially how far can one go to protect those they hold dear. A lot of anime try and tackle this question, and many do quite a great job. However, what this anime does especially well is demonstrate the blinding effect that brotherly love can have (for context, the main two characters are twin brothers). \n\n
I cannot wait to watch the next saga to this anime, which (if you did not already know) is currently airing after a few years hiatus.

Even the final episode, a theatrical triumph of theatricality, while being particular, knows a little predictable, taken for granted.\n

In conclusion I can not help but recommend "Ao No Exorcist", first of all because it is a very special anime and has very original ideas, secondly because it was made almost flawlessly (perfection does not exist).

Suddenly, Rin begins to see what appears to see bugs, but they are completely ignored by everyone except him. Those bugs are in reality, small demons that focus on evil people and possess then. This leads to a series of events, which endrevealing the true identity of Rin, he is in truth a human-demon hybrid, whose father is none less than Satan himself. His brother doesn´t have any demonic powers, and Rin´s powers were sealed inside the demom-slaying blade Kurikura, which is beginning to fail to completely seal Rin´s powers, attracting a group of demons to attack the monastery in which he lives and kill Shirou (he is possessed by Satan, who is only able to possess Rin and Shirou, since only they are powerful enough to be his vessels). After that, Shirou is revealed to be a Paladin, the highest ranking member of the True Cross Order, a group of exorcists, which Rin joins so he can become strong enough to defeat Satan.\n
Ao no Exorcist is a 25 episode anime that presents a interesting history which develops slowly at the beginning, but reveal itself to be fast-paced after the third episode. The characters are well developed, interesting and pretty much unique, in spite of following some stereotypes ( Bon is the one who becomes a exorcist to avenge the “destruction” of his shrine; Izumo is somewhat tsundere; Shiemi is the shy one; even Rin being the sun of Satan isn´t at all a original concept). The artwork and the history are also another strong point in this anime, but the OST is nearly always ignored by the viewers (with the exception of the “Exorcist”, and the second opening; both endings are simply bad and the first opening is decent).\n
The greatest weakness of Ao no Exorcist is without doubt that from episode 17 onwards, there is not a single “canonical” episode… yes, this means that 25% of this anime is a filler arc. By another words, Ao no Exorcist joins the group of manga adaptations who were released to early and because of that becomes different from the manga; even so, to my own surprise, the filler arc is well accomplished and remains interesting unlike the filler arcs from the Three Great series (I am referring to Naruto, Bleach and One Piece, and no I do not hate them, in fact I am a great fan of Naruto and Bleach but both of them presents us some really boring fillers, like the Bount arc and the Konoha History arc).\n
Another necessary point that must be refered is that this is a shounen anime, so more mature viewers will probably dislike it. Also, although the anime itself is quite addictive, in my opinion it misses the most important thing in any history, that is the viewer doesn´t feel really connected with the characters with a exception for Rin and Yukio.\n
Conclusion: Ao no Exorcist is a good anime, I would give it 7 out of 10 points. The history is interesting and quite addictive, the graphics are good, and the characters, although stereotyped are interesting and well explored. The weak point in this anime is most certainly the music, which is nearly always ignored by the viewers. The lack of attachment to the characters and the fact that the filler arc is huge can also be negative factors to some of the viewers.\n
This article is only my opinion and therefore you may completely disagree with it.\n\n

Shonen series are often a hit or miss for me personally. Some of them can be really good and instantly draw me in with its premise (i.e FMA Brotherhood) and some can often fail to capture my attention (i.e Fairy Tail). 
Ao no Exorcist (also known as Blue Exorcist in the US) thankfully leans more towards the former.
Its premise drew me in straight away with its great character designs, the 'Supernatural' style chemistry between the two leads, an amazing 'Harry Potter' style school setting that we have yet to see outside of Negima and the overseeing struggle between humans and demons. After reading the firstfew chapters I was instantly hooked, eager to read more about the journey of these two Okamura brothers. When I discovered an anime was in the works I was delighted. I could finally see this work of art in its full animated and visually impressive glory. 


Story (5)

The story of Ao no Exorcist basically revolves around Rin Okamura who is the son of the demon lord known as Satan. After his father kills his guardian Shiro, he decides to take vengeance on his death by vowing to hunt down Satan and enrolling in True Cross Academy's cram school to become an exorcist. The greatest strength of Ao no Exorcist's story lies within the first half of the series, aka the half that actually follows the manga. While some scenes were altered, they were actually changed for the best. Episode 2 in particular was very well executed in both emotion, atmosphere and voice acting and to be was one of the very few occasions in which the anime managed to be better than the manga. The school scenes in particular were highly detailed and showcased a lot of supernatural features almost reminiscent of the 'Harry Potter' series. As a shonen itself, the manga and anime stands out amongst other 'Shonen Jump' franchises such as 'Naruto' and 'Bleach' by becoming more of a coming of age/journey-based shonen like many young adult novels and manga such as 'Fullmetal Alchemist' rather than your stereotypical battle manga with tournament arcs and friendship powerups. Granted there are still cliches that remind you its a shonen, but it doesn't seem to be overused like other series. The first half of the anime focuses more on the school life experience with audiences being treated to interesting scenes in which we learn more about the demons and analyze ways in which to combat them. It allows for a refreshing take on the shonen genre that usually consists of characters going through various powerups to become stronger. There's very little of that here for characters actually learn their skills through a classroom setting.


So far it was a great adaptation. Sadly that did not last very long. Once the second half rolled along the anime soon diverted away from the manga to suddenly set in to tell its own original tale. The anime original part of this anime which begins at the end of episode 15 and carries on until the final episode had failed to captivate me as much as the first half did. Instead the anime had me nodding off at how uninteresting it made the characters seem, the dull plot that seemed to be too generic of most other action series and the introduction of a villain who seemed too 1-dimensional to me. Needless to say I did not care so much for the series. I wished the anime would instead adapt the more superior Impure King arc which while it had its fair share of flaws had managed to create a rather interesting and compelling story. 


There are also two noticeable flaws that irritated me. The first was that there are 3 filler episodes that contribute little to the overall story. The first one had some comedic moments but the other two were simply a pain to sit through. The second gripe I had with this anime's storyline was the lack on depth on some of the characters past and background. I want to see more of Bon's family and more of Izumo's rather tragic looking past as shown through a short 1 minute flashback, but the anime does not touch on this issue again.


Art and animation (8)

The animation in Ao no Exorcist was done by A1 Pictures who were also responsible for animes such as 'Black Butler', 'Working!' and later went on to animate popular works such as 'Sword Art Online'. For the most part it is clear that they had some pretty good funding for the animation is rich and detailed with character designs looking very similar to the manga. The fights were relatively fluid and also fast-paced so you won't have characters constantly staring at each other during fights like some of the well known shonen adaptations. I was also particularly fond of the blue flames that the demons and Rin's sword let off.


Sound (10)

Sawano Hiroyuki completely nails the soundtrack for this anime. The music for this anime is covered with ominous and demonic chants, some epic choir scores that would make other orchestral soundtracks envious and the expert use of a violin during the more emotional and relaxing tracks. No OST sounds the same, each one is different from the other while still maintaining an outstanding quality throughout. There is so much goodness in here to list that it would take me all day to gush about it. So I am going to recommend you to listen to the soundtrack! It is absolutely worth it!


Character (6) 

The characters within this series in both the manga and anime are what I would consider to be some of the weaker aspect of both mediums. Rin to be me came off as a rather typical shonen protagonist with his determination to never give up fighting and always jumping headfirst into all out brawls. The relationship between him and his brother Yukio was handled pretty well with some sequences involving the two working together to defeat their foes. Their chemistry reminded me of Sam and Dean Winchester from the 'Supernatural' series so if you like that show you may find this choice appealing to you. 


The other characters however felt undeveloped apart from Shiemi who evolves from a shy lonely girl to one who is determined to protect her friends no matter what. There's one character that is smart but aggressive towards the main lead (almost like a Sasuke from the 'Naruto' series), another who appears to be fitting the role of a comic relief, another who is so full of herself, another who is your stereotypical team pet, another who appears to be there to introduce some fanservice and so forth. So to be true to my opinions, I found a lot of them to be rather generic. 


Overall (6)

This series was a rather huge disappointment to me personally. It started off so promising but later collides off the rails into a cluttered mess of unappealing original characters, unlikable plot lines and twists and a final battle that is as generic as other shonen series out there. However despite all this I can definitely understand the popularity. It has some good supernatural elements to it, an absolutely outstanding soundtrack, some exhilarating battles and an interesting world which encourages you to want to find out more about it. So my recommendation is that if you are a fan of supernatural shonen along the lines of 'D Gray Man' or 'Soul Eater' then give this one a try or at least read the manga version whose second arc completely trumps the anime original arc.

Note: when I rate different anime, I am comparing them with only the other anime in my list. Ao no Exorcist is "Fine (6)" compared with the ~80 other series on my list. By itself, however, I would easily call this series "Very Good" or 8 out of 10. Though unoriginal in some aspects, "Ao no Exorcist" is a superbly made, exciting, and humorous fantasy/supernatural series.
The characters are simply adorable: in animation, development, and not to mention sound-- several excellent voice actors such as Kana Hanazawa feature in "Ao no Exorcist." The excellent writing managed to make the story  charming and exciting, despite someunoriginal tropes (the son fighting the father, the boy who is part demon, the universe comprised of two domains like earth and a spirit world, an overpowered main character, childish jokes, etc.). A few elements were refreshingly original, however, such as the system of magic used by Exorcists. The psychological nature of the backstory of Rin's mother is particularly surprising in an anime that is often more light-hearted. In fact, that's my favorite aspect of the series, this backstory of Rin's mother and its implications to that world's "Church".


Why should you watch it? If you want a funny and action-packed fantasy tale, "Ao no Exorcist" is a great choice, especially if you're looking for something that isn't twenty seasons long. If you like supernatural stories where there's a god and a satan, as well as any other magical creatures, again "Ao no Exorcist" is great. 


Finally, regarding the anime's treatment of "The Church", it is acceptable for Christians, since there is a God and Satan. But it's also acceptable for minority religions where demons or spirits are worshiped, because the "demons" of this Series are not entirely evil. In this way, I think it attracts a larger audience. 


So try it out if you want some explosive fantasy fun.

Shounen? Demons? Was this just a Kuroshitsuji rip-off?
Not at all. 
I wasn't expecting to like this series, but it really amazed me and I can safely say that it's one of my favourite anime. 
However,  every anime has flaws, so I'll do my best not to rave about this one and point out criticisms.
Story :: 7
The story, as far as I know, isn't something that's been done before. It struck me as a unique and engaging plot, with a lot of potential. While Ao No Exorcist did come running out of the gate and got me hooked almost immediately, it did begin to slowdown in the middle of the series. I have to admit that I was a bit bored watching several of the episodes, sitting around and waiting for the plot to move forward. Nevertheless, even the trivial episodes do contribute a bit to the plot and character development. It's simply unfortunate that they didn't keep the "adrenaline", shall I say, going. Ao No Exorcist does have a great ending, though, and I'm glad I persevered through the impatience!


Art :: 9

I'm rather picky about the art in the animes I watch, but Ao No Exorcist most certainly fulfilled my expectations. The action scenes, which are perhaps the most vital, are well-drawn, and the demons, also an integral part of the plot, are mostly uniquely designed, though at times they don't always appear, well, intimidating. Regardless, I did like the designs of all the characters, who are easily distinguishable due to their different physical qualities that set them apart from each other. Alas, with all the blue flames and darkness, the backgrounds don't receive much attention. The only ones that I can say stood out are Shiemi's garden. It is necessary to take into consideration that the exorcists are attending a school where there won't be many ornate designs, though. My last complaint about the art would be the exaggerated "angry faces" of Rin, something that I would describe as Eren Jaeger-esque, though perhaps not as ridiculous-looking. Though it helps to convey emotion, it can sometimes look comical and detract from the seriousness of battles or situations. 


Sound :: 7

The background music doesn't stand out at all. This is both good and bad; it's not extraordinary enough to take notice of, but then again it also complements what's happening in the anime. Personally, I would have preferred for the background music to be more memorable. As for the OPs and EDs, I did enjoy all of them, though I really love the OP and ED from the first season and the ED from the second season. Pay attention to Meisa Kuroki's "Wired Life", which is the second ending of the series, I think that the lyrics are beautiful and it's as though the song is made perfectly for Ao No Exorcist [ though they can also apply to life as well ]. 


Character :: 8

One of the things I appreciated most about Ao No Exorcist is that each character is distinguished from the others. I can name at least five unique personality or history traits about each character, even some of the background characters. Every one of the many characters gets a little bit of back story and thus I really felt as though I could understand them more due to this. Some of them, however, didn't enjoy as much development as they could have had. I empathized with a lot of the characters as they faced moral conflicts. Additionally, there was a clear distinction between Rin and Yukio, despite the fact that they are twins. However, the part where Ao No Exoricst fails is in adequately developing Yukio's character. At the end of the series, I still don't know that much about him, except that he wants the best for his brother and is determined to keep him safe. If you put the brotherly devotion aside, though, there isn't much left.


Enjoyment :: 9

I prefer slice-of-lifes, so watching Ao No Exorcist was really a result of having no other anime to watch on Netflix. Thus, it was a wonderful surprise to find that I really enjoyed this anime! I can't give this a 10 because it's not the best anime I've ever watched, due to the errors listed above and the aforementioned slowing down of the series in the middle that made me wonder if I should even finish it. Though Ao No Exorcist redeemed itself by the end, I can't say that I enjoyed the entirety of the series.


Overall :: 9

If you're looking for an action-filled anime with a unique plot, characters that you can relate to or simply be entertained by, and not have to dwell on dark themes or plot holes, then Ao No Exorcist might be good for you. The end of this series was not a cliffhanger in the least and left me with no outstanding questions that will nag me for all of eternity, so fear not! It is by far not the most engaging anime or the best that you will ever watch, but some of the messages in it will resonate with you.

Whether it’s a book, a movie or an anime, I always love it when there’s supernatural theme in them. So after crying my eyes out watching Your Lie in April, I decided to look for some supernatural anime and tadah! I came across Blue Exorcist (Ao no Exorcist). It’s honestly my first time hearing about this anime so I don’t really know what to expect. But when I watched its very first episode, I was really surprised how it easily captured my attention.
As usual, for this review, I am going to break up my thoughts through the following points:
Plot
I absolutely LOVE the plot plus Ilove that it was straight to the point and gave me what I wanted. There’s no dilly dallying and Blue Exorcist gave me action as early as its first episode. We can already guess that this anime is going to include some praying and chanting so I kind of anticipated some boring chanting scenes in this anime, but surprise, there’s none. There was obviously some chanting and reference about Vatican and church and things like that, but for me I guess that made this anime even more interesting. Plus the exorcists here we’re kind of badass, *wink.


There are only 12 episodes in each season but it felt enough for me to get to know the important characters especially, Rin. Personally, I prefer season 1 from season 2. The second season was kind of a letdown for me, there’s some slight difference from the first season plus I wasn’t a fan of the drama. But it was still a decent watch though, plus the final episode was really cute.


Characters

I absolutely love the main character. It also didn’t help that he has a twin brother (I’m a sucker for twins!) but unlike him, didn’t inherit their father’s power until on the last few episodes in season 1. The character development was good too and I love seeing how Rin is improving in controlling his power. He’s troublesome alright, but he genuinely like to help everyone and doesn’t want anyone to get hurt. His twin brother on the other hand is alright. Well, he was actually alright in the first season but he started to get under my nerves in the second season. His issues are warranted but it’s just annoying to watch, that’s all.


And speaking of annoying, there’s this 1 particular character that I learned to hate when I watch season 2. She’s so annoying that I just mentally erased her entire existence in this anime, haha lol. Excluding her, I actually think that Blue Exorcist has some great character line-up plus I love Kuro!


Animation/Graphics

I absolutely love the animation and think it was of high quality. From facial expressions to background scenery, everything is just so pleasing to look at plus the character designs are also excellent. The animation studio should be proud of their work in this anime.



Soundtrack

The first time I heard Blue Exorcist’s OP and ED songs, I didn’t instantly became a fan. But as I get to listen to them everytime I watch a new episode, I learned to really appreciate the music. I guess you could say that it’s one of those that gets better everytime you hear them, *wink.


Plus, didn’t I tell you that Blue Exorcist is one of those rare anime that I watch from the very beginning ‘til its closing song in every episode? So yep, I guess that speaks a lot from this anime eh?



Voice Actors

I actually don’t have any complaints at all. I think the voice actors were able to portray each character so well, there’s no need for me to elaborate more eh?


Overall

Despite the letdown in season 2, overall, Blue Exorcist is still a very enjoyable watch for me. Haven’t read the manga counterpart yet but I’ve been hearing that it suffered from the usual adaptation pains, with a rushed ending and lack of power development which is quite unfortunate but luckily not enough to ruin the experience. It may not have reached greatness, I still think that Blue Exorcist is a good series to watch.


Rating: 8/10 – Very Good


Movie – I’ve seen it right after watching the first season and some may say it was more of the same but I genuinely enjoyed it. If you liked Blue Exorcist, be sure to check out the movie once you finish the series, *wink.

One has to ask the question whether a repeated formula for success is something that works because it works or is it something that gets very tiring, boring, old hat, and repetitive. The concept of a lead character in his teens having his world shattered with the truth about his or her birth or origins and being thrust into a world of magic where they are the one thing that stands in between the world and evil (often with a sword at their side) is something I have seen time and again in not just anime but many genres. "Ao no Exorcist" or "Blue Exorcist"does this same thing again, but it also does it well enough to keep a viewer's interest and entertain them along the way.


The story revolves around teenage Rin and his brother Yukio, the former being the rough around the edges delinquent type and the latter being a more studious, straight laced kid. One has constant bedhead and the other has short hair and glasses. The are opposites, but the sense of brotherhood between these two is well established. They don't always get along, but they do watch out for each other. They live in a world where demons exist and come into our world via demonic possession. Exorcists are there to deal with these fiends. Their father is one of the best around, while also being a loving and caring man. Then, the plot kicks in. Their father is killed during a confrontation with Satan himself, the truth that Rin and Yukio are both children born of Satan (but with only Rin inheriting his true father's blood- not that the pointed ears and fangs was hint enough) and the two are sent to True Cross Academy, a veritable Hogwarts if ever there was one, and their education in demon fighting begins. Because if anime didn't take place in a school, it might not take place at all.


It is here the anime really starts. After such a ghoulish opening with lots of blood and the proverbial sh*t getting real, it then becomes a school story, with lots of humor and the daily conflict of the day being resolved usually by episode's end. A supporting cast is introduced, fellow students, teachers, and the school president- Sir Mephisto Pheles (a name not given to him by accident) each establishing themselves as notable, if not somewhat cliched, side kicks. True Cross Academy itself is very much like Hogwarts or other magically inclined schools, but it is not without it's own individuality. It's normal enough to pass for a school, but has it's own quirks so that it's a fun place to want to see more of. 


While the action in this show is fair to mediocre, the show itself does remind viewers of what the stakes are. That Satan and his cohorts are out there and prove themselves to be worth and vicious adversaries. A very PG-13 atmosphere if ever there was one, where the bad guys are capable of some very awful things with blood and a body count not beyond the realm of possibilities, but still keeping it tame enough that viewers aren't going to crap their pants. I think this is where the show finds itself a comfortable level and manages to produce a product that appeals to many viewers. Fun, action oriented, and with just enough spooky to catch some off guard. 


A strong artwork showing also helps this show along. Many of the demons and characters on display are creatively designed critters that are neat to look at. They use many tropes of anime with exaggerated reactions and funny faces, it is a cartoon after all, but when the spooky stuff does come out it has the same care and attention to it as the fun stuff. A wonderfully balanced contrast as one would come to expect from the fabulous studio that is A-1 Pictures. Adding in a wonderful cast in both the Sub and Dub categories with many well known veterans on either side giving typically strong performances and I feel safe recommending either one depending on your preference.

The build up to the ending is strong with some twists to be had but one I frankly found to be underwhelming, but I must also allow the premise that this is but the beginning of what appears to be a franchise that is here to stay. Don't expect the world from this series or see it as a knock off of something else, it is what it is. A solid 7/10 from top to bottom. It's french fries in a world trying to constantly re-invent the potato. Check it out. Cheers!

The Blue Exorcist was a refreshing addition to the Shounen anime genre, providing viewers with a new representation of the plot and characters one might have viewed earlier in series such as Naruto. The positive part of the series is the introduction of the occult, the protagonist's relationship with his brother. This anime is a by the numbers Shounen, i.e., (i) the typical scarred childhood; (ii) death of a father figure; (iii) becoming and outcast; (iv) having extraordinary potential/raw power; and (v) friends assisting the protagonist in overcoming his obstacles (making up for the feels). Despite the stereotypical plot the anime manages to pour ina life of its own due to the theme being displayed by it, and the exceptionally well portrayed characters of Yukio Okumura (who has much more depth than the protagonist) and Phelis Mehpisto (who will keep you guessing and in suspense for the entire duration of the series). The animation is remarkable and the background score definitely makes the show gripping at the crucial moments, making you hooked onto the series despite the simplistic story. The choreography of several action sequences has also been executed with great sophistication, which makes the show all the more enjoyable. Overall the show is visually appealing, and a good way to pass some time. However, it comes nowhere close to pulling off emotional scenes or character development as compared to Naruto. Therefore, all in all this series is definitely good, just not one of the best out there.

Okay, I'm not gonna lie, I wasn't completely hooked at first. I think I had to get through the first few episodes of story setup before I really started enjoying it. 
However, I did come to love the characters quite a lot. Also, I loved watching Rin learn about his powers and himself and Yukio. His character development was really amazing. 
From what I read, the last eight episodes of this first season isn't in the manga, which is kind of a shame because I actually really liked the ending of the first season. I thought the characters' developments came to a nice close forthe season while still leaving some plot holes open for the future. All in all, the first season of Blue Exorcist was amazing. I definitely recommend watching it.

My anime friends loved this anime, and I had to check it out for myself recently.
To say i was disappointed would be unfair, but to say i understood why they loved it, would be a lie. 
For every great moment the main characters undertake, learning more about themselves, becoming stronger, or a great plot moment that makes you click on the next episode, there are several more moments of stale dialogue, generic shonen tropes, and boring exposition about the boring back story of characters you dont have a reason to care about.
That is not to say it is a bad anime however. It's just... there.The magic, as well as it's place in the world is solid. The main character, Rin, is a protagonist you would want to root for. The lore of the world is extensive. The villains and obstacles are varied and interesting. \n\n
It is a great concept, and offers something new to your list, as it isn't just "generic." I love the concept as a whole, but as far as the execution of those ideas, it falls short. I simply did not find it to have the staying power of other anime to want to come back and watch more.\n\n
Blue Exorcist is definitely worth your time. However, I cannot see it as being much more than something that is on in the background, or a series to watch until you find something you actually want to get into.\n\n
Overall, it is a solid 6/10.

Ao no Exorcist is a truly underrated anime, with a creative storyline
The show is about Rin Okumura, who is the son of Satan. After he finds out when he's older and goes through a tragic incident, Rin applies goes to True Cross Academy to become an exorcist, and makes friends, enemies, and complicated relationships along the way, while also learning how to control his powers and emotions through friendship and bravery.
What I love about this show is that it has a powerful lesson about self control. Rin learns throughout the series that in order to win fights, he must control himself instead of going berserkagainst his enemy, focusing on simply destroying his enemy. I also love the creativity of the show, the story is imaginative and the designs for the demons are very unique, ranging from adorable to terrifying.\n\n
The show also handles it's emotional moments really well. I have to admit, there were a couple of moments in the show where I got a little teary eyed because I could relate to the message about trusts in friendships a lot, since I have trust issues because of how my previous friends treated me in the past. I gets to me on a personal level and I admire that the show does that.\n\n
Overall, Ao no Exorcist is one of my favourite animes, and I give it a 9/10, for its creativity, loveable characters, and very well handled emotional moments which reach to me personally.

Blue Exorcist Review....
Here's my first review, Let me know how I did :D
Blue Exorcist (Ao No Exorcist) 
Creator: Kazue Katō
Genres: Action, Comedy, Demons, Fantasy, Shounen, Supernatural, Dub
Does this review contain any spoliers? Uhh not really but the only spoiler I would see is when I was referring to a scene, that's about it..
Blue Exorcist also known as Ao No Exorcist is a fine wine anime for any shounen fan out there, or maybe someone who just desire for Shounen for the first time. Published by A-1 Pictures (Fairy Tail, Magi: The Kingdom of Magic, and numerous titles), Blue Exorcist delivers enjoyment along with its varietyof characters including AWESOME animation. The main focus is the ironic idea of a demon killing demons; not just any random demon, including Satan as well. The first episode jumps immediately into the storyline, which grabbed my attention (considering most animes doesn’t do that). The dope soundtrack produced by Hiroyuki Sawano (Attack on Titan, Kill La Kill) keeps bringing that fire through the battle scenes.\n\n
This 25 episode anime had an original ending, although I feel one of the weaknesses of Blue Exorcist it felt a tad bit rushed and unfocused. Another weakness would be, there were many unnecessary filler episodes, but hey at least they do focus on the other characters (firing up on each character's development). Overall the series conclusion was not focused on until the last few episodes.\n\n
I’m pretty sure as I mentioned before the series offers a great variety of characters along with different personalities, and most of the filler episodes help characterize them. Each character is seen as they own person, each with just the right amount of screen time (not too much nor too little). Perhaps one could relate themselves to another character because of this?\n\n
If you are looking for an anime with a simple yet fire storyline(pun intended) , then I highly recommend Blue Exorcist. The scenes themselves will have you speechless, while others might have you dying of laughter (One scene would be (Spoiler Alert): where the group is camping and Yukio Okumura is going on about the rules and such, he also mention Kirigakura Shura birthday, which she cut him off by throwing an empty drink can and said “Uh-oh my hand slip,” thus angering Yukio and he replied “Cut the shit and get to work already” she then said “Look I made him mad.” Considering the fact she was drunk makes it funnier.) \n\n
Upon watching this series you would want to immediately continue to the next episode, until you reached the ending. Whether you may be an anime veteran or just a plain rookie on the sidelines, you would fall in love with this series.

Ao no Exorcist is about a guy who happens to be a demon spawn. As a result, everyone is extremely scared of him or wants to kill him, which is what makes it so interesting.
Story 8/10
No, it's not the most original thing ever. But this kind of outline story always leaves room for the author (of the manga) or director (of the show) to place their own twist on it.
One of my rules for any anime is, if I'm not enraptured by the first episode, I don't watch it. Yup, I'm picky like that. However, this one just yanked me right in. Forget the loopholes(which, by the way, there isn't any); every episode will make you watch the next up until the very end.


Art 7/10

The main aspect I want to talk about is the females. The female portrayal is excellent in my opinion; I've never seen a (relatively new) anime that has such a variety. Usually, the females are for fanservice so they all have that same cutesy look. And I'm talking about multiple animes, not just one show. But this show has more quality to it and it really shows. And not just the character art, but the other demons and the scenery as well.


Sound

I'm not one to judge for sound. When the music stands out, I can give it praise and a higher rating but this one was pretty normal as any show.


Character 9/10

Despite the MC being a demon and all, he's utterly realistic and has his flaws. Yes, ladies and gentlemen: flaws. He gets beat up all the time and every time he stands back up, you can see the character development. That's right! Character development! The other characters were developed as well as they warmed up to their strange friend.


Enjoyment 9/10

I will say: I thoroughly enjoyed this one. Is it the best? Well...no. But it isn't the show's fault. This was my first shounen, and it was quite interesting, but because of the target audience there were some things that were missing that I wanted more of.


Overall 9/10

If I were you, I would give the first episode a try. It's a good length, so if you like it the show will hold for a while. Every episode is equally as good as the last and despite some flaws here and there, it really was a solid 9/10 for me.

Typical but not ordinary...
